```{
    "ExtensionsWithNoOutput": [ ".d.ts" ]
  },
  "CodeCoverageExcludes": [ ".spec.ts" ],
  "References": [

  ],
  "Tests": [
    {
      "Path": "UnitTests",
      "Includes": [ "*/*.spec.ts" ],
      "Excludes": [ "*/*.d.ts", "*/**.spec.js" ],
      "ExpandReferenceComments": "true"
    }
  ]

}
```
Chutzpah.json is placed one directory level above utils.ts and utils.spec.ts

Is it required to build the .ts files to .js files before running the tests? If yes, then is there a workaround.
If no, then what is the issue?

title: QUnit tests disappear from the Test Explorer window after debugging tests
body:
I'm using VS2017 Enterprise 15.7.4 with Chutzpah test runner and adapter 4.3.6. I have a simple repro solution with only 1 test. When I open it, tests are discovered and they are listed in the Test Explorer. If I debug my tests using right click/Debug Tests (CTRL+R CTRL+T), Internet Explorer is shown and breakpoints work fine. After the debug is stopped, all the tests in the test file disappear from the Test Explorer and there are some exceptions in the Tests output window. Even if I try to run the tests using right click/Run Tests (CTRL+R T), no tests are run. In the Tests output window, there's a message saying ```[2018-06-22 3:47:35 PM Informational] No tests found to run.```. The only workaround is to modify the test file and save the file so that Chutzpah rediscover the tests which is far from ideal.

**Steps**
1. Create an empty ASP.NET project.
2. Configure Typescript to compile AMD modules.
3. Add the following files to the unit test projects.
4. Let VS2017 discover the QUnit tests.
5. Debug the chutzpah.test.ts file using right-click/Debug Tests 

**Actual behavior**
Tests disappear from the Test Explorer.

Tests output window exceptions
```
The program '[35416] testhost.x86.exe' has exited with code 0 (0x0).
The program '[35416] testhost.x86.exe: Program Trace' has exited with code 0 (0x0).
'iexplore.exe' (Script): Loaded 'Script Code (Windows Internet Explorer)'. 
Exception was thrown at line 33, column 7 in file:///C:/USERS/<user>/APPDATA/LOCAL/MICROSOFT/VISUALSTUDIO/15.0_3EDF193E/EXTENSIONS/LJYC4WPR.WRN/ChutzpahTestHarnessFiles/QUnit/v1/qunit.js
0x800a138f - JavaScript runtime error: Unable to get property 'setItem' of undefined or null reference
Exception was thrown at line 206, column 7 in file:///C:/USERS/<user>/APPDATA/LOCAL/MICROSOFT/VISUALSTUDIO/15.0_3EDF193E/EXTENSIONS/LJYC4WPR.WRN/ChutzpahTestHarnessFiles/QUnit/v1/qunit.js
0x80004005 - JavaScript runtime error: unknown exception
Exception was thrown at line 2390, column 9 in file:///C:/USERS/<user>/APPDATA/LOCAL/MICROSOFT/VISUALSTUDIO/15.0_3EDF193E/EXTENSIONS/LJYC4WPR.WRN/ChutzpahTestHarnessFiles/QUnit/v1/qunit.js
0x800a138f - JavaScript runtime error: Unable to get property 'setItem' of undefined or null reference
'iexplore.exe' (Script): Loaded 'Sourcemap (file:///c:/users/<user>/documents/visual studio 2017/projects/poc_chutzpah/poc_chutzpah/scripts/chutzpah/chutzpah.test.js)'. 
Exception was thrown at line 206, column 7 in file:///C:/USERS/<user>/APPDATA/LOCAL/MICROSOFT/VISUALSTUDIO/15.0_3EDF193E/EXTENSIONS/LJYC4WPR.WRN/ChutzpahTestHarnessFiles/QUnit/v1/qunit.js
0x80004005 - JavaScript runtime error: unknown exception
'iexplore.exe' (Script): Unloaded 'Sourcemap (file:///c:/users/<user>/documents/visual studio 2017/projects/poc_chutzpah/poc_chutzpah/scripts/chutzpah/chutzpah.test.js)'
The program '[15956] iexplore.exe' has exited with code 0 (0x0).
```

**Expected behavior**
Tests don't disappear from the Test Explorer.

Here is the content of my simple repro project.

packages.json
```json
{
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "name": "poc_chutzpah",
  "private": true,
  "devDependencies": {
    "@types/qunit": "2.5.1",
    "@types/requirejs": "2.1.31"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "requirejs": "2.3.5"
  }
}
```

chutzpah.json:
```json
{
    "Framework": "qunit",
    "TestHarnessReferenceMode": "AMD",
    "TestHarnessLocationMode": "SettingsFileAdjacent",
    "TypeScriptModuleKind": "AMD",
    "References": [
        { "Path": "require.js" },
        { "Path": "chutzpah/config.js" }
    ],
  "Tests": [
    {
      "Path": "chutzpah",
      "Includes": [ "*.test.ts" ]
    }
  ]
}
```

chutzpah/config.js
```javascript
require.config({
    paths: {},
    shim: {}
});
```

chutzpah/chutzpah.test.ts:
```typescript
QUnit.module("chutzpah");

QUnit.test("repro", assert => {
    assert.ok("ok");
});
```

Let me know if you prefer to have a repro project.

title: VSTest not detecting chutzpah-jasmine tests
body:
Hi Matthew,

Hope you're doing well. Was wondering if you'd be able to please help me out with the following? -

I'm trying to setup chutzpah + jasmine unit test for a sample project but unlike the online tutorials, my unit tests are not being picked up by Visual Studio's test explorer. Have detailed more about it below.

### What I have set up
* I've installed both Visual Studio extensions [[1]](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vs-publisher-2795.ChutzpahTestRunnerContextMenuExtension), [[2]](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vs-publisher-2795.ChutzpahTestAdapterfortheTestExplorer).
* I have a `chutzpah.json` file in the root of my solution (repo link attached at the bottom).
* I have installed the chutzpah nuget package (tried the latest and also tried 4.1.0 as per reference link attached at the bottom).
* Working on Visual Studio Community 2017 (I've also tried the same on VS professional 2017).
* Out-of-the-box MVC web app and I'm only trying to test a JS 'helper' file. 

### What doesn't work
* Visual Studio Test Explorer doesn't detect the unit tests.
* When I right-click a file and click 'Run JS tests', it gives me the following in the output window.
```
------ Test started: File: C:\Users\<username>\Documents\GitHub\jasmine-chutzpah-jsunittest-demo\Calculator.Web\Scripts\tests\app\appHelper.test.js ------
0 passed, 0 failed, 0 total (chutzpah).
========== Total Tests: 0 passed, 0 failed, 0 total ==========
```
* When I go to the packages folder -> chutzpah version folder -> tools and run `chutzpah.console.exe` in command prompt and give my web solution path OR `chutzpah.json` file as parameters, it gives me the same output as above.
* When I run `vstest.console.exe` and pass the `...test.js' file and the test adapter path (as mentioned in the reference link mentioned below), I get the following message:
```
No test is available in C:\Users\<username>\Documents\GitHub\jasmine-chutzpah-jsunittest-demo\Calculator.Web\Scripts\tests\app\appHelper.test.js. Make sure that test discoverer & executors are registered and platform & framework version settings are appropriate and try again.
```
* When I try an online build in VSTS, I get the similar message as above. It's able to find the appHelper.test.js file but then talks about test discoverer...etc.
  

### What works
* When I right-click a `...test.js` file and click 'open in browser', a Jasmine HTML test (SpecRunner HTML) page gets generated with all my tests passing/failing. 
  

### Links
Reference link: https://www.henrihietala.fi/running-jasmine-unit-tests-in-your-visual-studio-online-build/
Repository: https://github.com/ClydeDz/jasmine-chutzpah-jsunittest-demo

Thanks,
Clyde

title: Fix Issue#712: When running via the RunTests(), the TestCaseSummary() is missing information in case of time out
body:
Currently, if one js test in the file timed out, the remaining tests in that file will not run. The TestCaseSummary shows 0 tests passed, 0 tests fail, and 0 tests skipped.

As can be found from the logs, there actually are tests passed before the timed out test. However, the passed tests are not in the TestCaseSummary. The reason is that the TestCaseStreamReader() just returns an empty TestFileSummary, loosing those test results which have already finished.

This pull request adds not ran tests and the timed out test into TestFileSummary. Then TestCaseStreamReader.Read() return the existing TestFileSummary() no matter timed out or not.

Thanks,
Melissa

title: TypeScript coverage - only spec files are covered as TypeScript (VS test runner)
body:
We use the [Chutzpah Test Runner Context Menu Extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vs-publisher-2795.ChutzpahTestRunnerContextMenuExtension).  It works great for JavaScript, and pretty well for TypeScript, but I've been unable to get TypeScript code coverage to work the way we want it to.  Specifically, I've been trying to set it up to show the coverage on the TypeScript files, instead of the generated JavaScript files.  I've even gotten it working for the spec files, but it seems pretty set on showing the JavaScript for the files under test:
![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37372562/37405522-dae2c662-2762-11e8-8f22-48629f042ea8.png)

I've tried every combination of settings I can think of for the chutzpah.json file, with the results so far either being the same, or things just not working.  I also enabled tracing, but didn't see much that looked applicable to my (admittedly inexperienced at reading Chutzpah traces) eyes: [chutzpah.log](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/files/1811336/chutzpah.log) However, I may still have missed some way to get things working.

I spent some time to come up with something close to the smallest possible project to reproduce the issue in Visual Studio 2017:
[Chutzpah Test.zip](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/files/1811251/Chutzpah.Test.zip)
It also opens and shows the issue in 2015 -- let me know if it's not working in your preferred version and I'll see what I can do.

I'm hoping for one of two outcomes:
1. If there are changes we can make to any of the following files in that project to get things working, I should be able to apply that to our actual code:
- chutzpah.json (seems the most likely)
- tsconfig.json
- Toolbox.ts
- ToolboxSpec.ts
Changes to other files in the project are less certain to be directly applicable, but I'm willing to try them out.  We can't realistically stop using AMD modules or Jasmine.
2. If this is actually a bug in Chutzpah or the extension, hopefully the smallish test case helps it get reproduced and fixed.

Please let me know if I can provide any additional information.

My test file looks like:

```JavaScript
var mocha = require("mocha");
var should = require("should");

describe("Some basic testing",
    function () {
        describe("is defined",
            function () {
                (0).should.equal(0);
                (0).should.equal(0);
                [0, 1, 2].should.be.instanceof(Array).and.have.length(3);
            }
        );
    }
);
```

And I've got a ``Chutzpah.json`` that looks like:

```JavaScript
{
    "Framework": "mocha",
    "MochaInterface": "bdd",
    "References": [
        { "Path": "../node_modules/chai/chai.js" }
    ]
}
```

Which all I want to also facilitate via ``gulp``:

```JavaScript
gulp.task("test",
    function() {
        return gulp.src(cfg.tests + "/*.js", { read: false })
            .pipe(mocha({
                clearRequireCache: true,
                ignoreLeaks: true,
                exit: true
            }))
            .on("error", console.error);
    }
);
```

I expect to see results reported to the test runner, but what I am receiving is a ``Jasmine`` browser window with *"No spec found"*, which leads me to believe that somehow ``Jasmine`` is my test runner in spite of having installed ``Chutzpah``? Never mind, connecting Mocha+Chai+Should-isms to the tests.

Thoughts?

title: Help me please!
body:
I am newbie with Chutzpah, recently I pull this repo and try to run test in vs 2017 pro, but there is no test found, although jasmine show all test in browser.
https://github.com/springcomp/TypeScript.Jasmine.Chutzpah.Sample

Could u please take a look this repo Manela. Thank you so much!

title: Test adapter make 'Test Explorer' take too long to find all tests (more than 15 minutes)
body:
Good day,

I've created a test project using Jasmine and Chutzpah and added  the **'Chutzpah Test Adapter for the Test Explorer'** and the **Chutzpah Test Runner Context Menu Extention'**  extentions, following this tutorial (https://developers.veinteractive.com/tech-blog/testing-javascript-chutzpah-vsts/). I've done it two times: one of then in a solution with only my JS tests project, and other in a solution with my web app other tests projects (Integration, Acceptance and Unit tests projects that are using NUnit, OpenQA.Selenium, FluentAssertions, etc).

In the first solution (the one that contains only the JS tests project), it worked really well. But, when I've added a JS test project following the same logic to my other solution, the Visual Studio's Test Explorer got really, really slow (it spend more than 15 minutes to find my tests - have in mind that, before I've used the extensions and created the JS tests project, it took, in worst case scenario, 2 minutes to find all my tests) to finally find all tests, including the JS ones.



Do you guys have any ideia of what might be happening? 

P.S. I am using Visual Studio 2017 in an ASP.Net net45 web project, Chutzpah 4.3.6, Jasmine 2.6.4, FluentAssertions 3.0.107, NUnit 2.6.3, NUnitTestAdapter 1.0, SpecFlow 2.2.1, Selenium.WebDriver 3.6.0, Selenium.Support 3.6.0 and some others

title: ReferenceErrors during Chutzpah+Jasmine+Ts+Angular test run
body:
Hello!

I'm trying to setup **Chutzpah** to run **Jasmine** Unit Tests with an **angular** and **typescript**.

And when I'm running test for the first time I receive errors like:

`ReferenceError: Can't find variable: SomeModule `

But .js usually generated and second test run goes ok.

repo:
[chutzpah-jasmine-angular](https://github.com/mihalycz/chutzpah-jasmine-angular)

Best Regards and Thank You!

title: Coverage reported on generated js files instead of ts files.
body:
I recently started working on a typescript project that uses Chutzpah for running ts unit tests and for generating code coverage.

I restructured code to redirect generated js output to a separate folder (previously all the generated JS files were in the same location as the ts source files). So, the current folder structure is 

**ProjectRoot
--ts
----src
----typings
----unittests
--js
----generated
--------src
--------unittests
tsconfig.json
chutzpah.json**

After I made this restructuring, I included an _OutputPath_ setting in the chutzpah.json.
    _"Paths": [
      {
        "OutputPath": "../js/generated",
        "OutputPathType": "Folder"
      }_

I have all the UTs passing. But, my coverage (coverage html)  is now being reported on JS files as opposed to TS files. Before this restructuring, the coverage html would report coverage on TS files.

Why did this change? What am I missing?

title: VS2017 test adapter discovering same test multiple times
body:
I have a project with some TypeScript code that I'd like to test. My tests are placed in a folder `Scripts`, the code under test is places in `Scripts/references`. TypeScript transpiles to folder `jsTests`, the source files are accordingly placed in `jsTests/references`:

    (Solution)
    ├── jsTests/ (transpiled tests)
    │   └── references/ (transpiled source files)
    │   │   └── rulepartMember.js (and other)
    │   │
    │   └── breadcrumbTests.js
    │
    └── Scripts/ (TypeScript tests)
        ├── references/ (TypeScript source files)
        │   └── rulepartMember.ts (and other)
        │
        └── breadcrumbTests.ts
In my `chutzpah.json`, I have specified the compilation of my tests as external and where the tests are found:

    {
      "Framework": "jasmine",
      "TestHarnessReferenceMode": "AMD",
      "TestHarnessLocationMode": "SettingsFileAdjacent",
      "AMDBaseUrl": "jsTests",
      "AMDAppDirectory": "./",
      "Compile": {
        "Mode": "External",
        "Extensions": [ ".ts" ],
        "ExtensionsWithNoOutput": [ ".d.ts" ],
        "Paths": [
          {
            "SourcePath": "Scripts",
            "OutputPath": "jsTests"
          }
        ]
      },
      "Tests": [
        {
          "Path": "Scripts",
          "Excludes": ["**/references"]
        },
        {
          "Excludes": [ "jsTests" ]
        }
      ],
      "References": [
        { "Path": "node_modules/jquery/dist/jquery.js" },
        { "Path": "node_modules/jasmine/lib/jasmine.js" },
        { "Path": "node_modules/jasmine-fixture/dist/jasmine-fixture.js" },
        { "Path": "node_modules/jasmine-jquery/lib/jasmine-jquery.js" },
        { "Path": "node_modules/jstree/dist/jstree.js" },
        { "Path": "node_modules/sinon/pkg/sinon.js" },
        { "Path": "jsTests" }
      ]
    }

When executing the tests, only the file `breadcrumbTests.ts` should be considered a test file. However, a temporary html file is created for every file under `Scripts`, including the `references` folder. A warning is shown in the Tests-Output window:
> [29.12.2017 11:25:23 Warning] A test with the same name '(...)\scripts\references\rulepartmember.ts::(test name)' already exists. This test is not added to the test window.

title: VS2017 Test Explorer not discovering tests with variable declaration
Using the test adapter without the vs extension
body:
The nuget package has to be changed to be able discover and run the tests without the extension (like xunit does). Also the new PackageReference nuget format should be supported to run seamlessly with CI tools like TFVC

See here (relative solutions)
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/4837
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5803

For instance I want to have IE10 documentMode and not the default one.

title: Test Adapter - VS2017 Jasmine Test show up under 'external'
body:
Hi,

In VS2015 all jasmine unit test show up under the correct project name in the Test Explorer, but when I open up my solution in VS2017 all my jasmine unit tests show up under 'External' instead of the project names. 

Is there anything I have to change to have my unit test show up under the correct project name?

Thanks,

Marco

title: #672: Fix for the Chutzpah doesn't discover JS tests in which AmdPaths with Pascal case for the test modules are added
body:
Issue:
We have one project which has amdPath added for each JS files ( including test files). When I tried running tests using chutzpah on the project. I found that some portion of amdPath generated by chutzpah for the test files is still coming in lower case.

While I can see that as part of commit “5145879: fix path casing” done on 12 Nov 2017, @mmanela fixed most of the casing issue in the test file path generation. but we are still hitting into the test file path casing issue.

Fix
=====
Passing  lowerCase flag = false to NormalizeFilePath in the method FindScriptFiles()

title: Chutzpah doesn't discover JS tests in which AmdPaths with Pascal case for the test modules are added
body:
Issue:
We have one project which has amdPath added for each JS files ( including test files). When I tried running tests using chutzpah on the project. I found that some portion of amdPath generated by chutzpah for the test files is still coming in lower case.

While I can see that as part of  commit “[5145879](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/commit/5145879b821c284e7856621c6b856e76c37cbd4a): fix path casing”  done on  12 Nov 2017, @mmanela fixed most of the casing issue in the test file path generation. but we are still hitting into the test file path casing  issue.

```
>chutzpah.console.exe chutzpah.json
Chutzpah console test runner  (64-bit .NET 4.0.30319.42000)
```

title: FR: toolbar button to disable chutzpah's test discovery (was: VS2017 is telling me Chutzpah is a startup performance problem)
body:
When I launch VS 2017 (something happened in 2015), I can't run my unit tests for quite a while - maybe a minute or so. The green cylon bar just keeps going across the top of the test explorer. Then finally it stops and I can run it. 

I believe what is happening is that the Chutzpah test runner is scanning for the tests in all my JS files. I have about 5000 unit tests. 

I don't think this initial scan does anything useful. Sure it populates the list of unit tests in the test explorer but with 10,000 unit tests in there (another 5,000 for C#) the list of not run tests is of no value. And I think it does the scan all over again when I do ask it to run all the unit tests. 

Is this what is happening? Is Chutzpah running the scan on startup? Is there a way we can prevent that?

title: Chutzpah is a great tool but very hard to get up and running
body:
Hi MManela,
I appreciate all the time and effort you have taken in writing this great tool however after a day of trying to get it to work I've had to give up due to lack of time. I'm running VS 2017 Professional with an Angular 4 project and have tried:

1) Your sample angular 2 application (does to work when loading into VS 2017!)
2) Various other demos and samples in GitHub and the web (most also don't work in VS 2017)
3) Even tried to take a sample that does work (https://github.com/GeorgDangl/NetCoreHeroes) and them slowly migrate config files over to my non-working solution but still cannot get it to work.

The main problem is the chutzpah configuration and its interaction with the various testing frameworks such as karma and jasmine. Its really difficult to work it all out and some more guidance on the interactions between the various configs is needed. 

Tx

title: 75% of my tests fail, but only with chutzpah
body: Hi, i have opened every test html file i have and they all succeed 100% in Edge, Chrome and Firefox, but with chutzpah, 75% fails. Not sure if it's just PhantomJS or what's causing this. Any way i can assist in debugging these failures?

title: Run Chutzpah from VS Code
body:
I'd like to create a "Chutzpah Runner" extension for VS Code.
I'll probably start by only running Mocha tests, but I don't even know if what I want is possible yet.

The problem is that the Visual Studio plugin is not that useful for us, since we don't use Visual Studio for anything to do with Javascript and our generated "js" code is "hidden" from the solution (since it's transpiled) - and so the plugin can't find the tests and we have to "show hidden files" to right-click and run them. This works but I have an idea that suits us better...

We are missing the ability to run individual tests while working on them.
I'd like to show a little arrow alongside each (Mocha) test, in VS Code which, when clicked, would run that test using Chutzpah - and show the output somehow.

There'll be a range of problems to solve here like finding the .exe and using the config file, but I"m going to look into it.

title: /failOnError option for Chutzpah Test Runner
body:
Hi!

It would be nice if there was a way to use the options described in https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/wiki/Command-Line-Options in the Test Runner Visual Studio extension.

For example, I could avoid the situation in which having no expectations shows an error but the test passes.

Thank you 😃

title: "UseSourceMaps": true using vstest.console.exe generate FileNotFoundException Newtonsoft.Json

title: chutzpah.json being ignored when running tests from the ReSharper test explorer
body:
Having struggled with my chutzpah.json file being ignored, I finally discovered that if I right-click on a test project in the Visual Studio Solution Explorer and choose "Run JS Tests" then the file is read, the tests pass, and I get the results in the Output window.

Similarly, if I use the VS Test Explorer, it works fine.

However, if I use the ReSharper Unit Tests Explorer window, the chutzpah.json file is ignored and the tests fail.

Given the number of developers that use R#, is there any way to have the R# Test Explorer to work with Chutzpah? It's a pain to have to use two different windows to run tests.

title: Want to use  ES6 code in  jasmine can you suggest me the process
body: what changes i have to make in chutzpah.json to run my jasmine-es6 code

title: Including the underlying library file eg Mocha.js
body:
In the Samples/Basic/Mocha folder the tests references **mocha.js** - but it doesn't actually exist.

From the output, it looks like it ignores mocha.js if you include it anyway, in favor of the built-in mocha.js stored in the Chutzpah install directory.
```:Ignoring reference file 'mocha.js' as a duplicate reference to mocha```

Does this mean that we can "upgrade" the mocha library (or qunit/jasmine) by replacing the installed js with a later version?

Does it also mean there is a specific version of **chai.js** we must use if including it?

One reason I ask is because right now I have a **Mocha** test passing as HTML file but running the latest version of Chutzpah, using just a file, the same test fails

``` expected 'report/bob?' to equal 'report/bob'```
It's a minor string comparison difference, but this fail message from running Chutzpah is the first I've seen or heard of it... the exact same test always passes when I create a HTML template for it and run it in Mocha via the browser

I'm using the chai.should() syntax
```url.should.equal('report/bob')```

title: chutzpah_reference work tandem with config References?
body:
I'll get you a repro for this if you think it should work.

I have a problem where I've set up chutzpah.json with various "References"
Then, in the test itself, I reference the file being tested (as below)

But the js errors I get and the debug output confirms that the chutzpah reference is not being included.

Do you know if in-file references and config references are designed to work together - ie could it be purposeful or accidental design that only one of them can be used? Or do I presume I'm doing something wrong...

**In test file**
```/// <chutzpah_reference path="../../core/core.util.js" />```

**In config**
```"References" :  [
    { "Path": "lib/core/jquery.js" },
    { "Path": "lib/core", "Includes": ["*.js"], "Excludes": ["jquery.js", "*.min.js"] },
    { "Path": "common" },
```

title: Can we stop the web page being opened after running tests?
body:
I use the VS extension for Chutzpah, so can see and run my tests in the Unit Test Sessions window in VS. I don't need the web page that pops up every time you run the tests, and it's pretty annoying to have to close it each time.

Any way we can prevent this web page popping up?

Thanks

P.S. This is NOT a criticism of Chutzpah by the way! Chutzpah is excellent, I just don't want this web page :)

title: References section of chutzpah.json being ignored

title: Issue with code coverage when using webpack build
body:
Hi,

I recently switched to webpack module loader/bundler and could manage all test cases to ve discover-able in test case explorer but not able to get the code coverage.

I tried Chtuzpah context menu option "Run chutzpah with>Coverage". 
Below is my Chutzpah.json

```
{
"Compile":{
"Mode":"External"
},
"References":[
{"Path":"common,bundle.js"}// framework
{"Path":"app,bundle.js"}// application code
],
"Tests":[
{"Path":"test.bundle.js"}// all test cases
],
"EnableCodeCoverage":"true",
"CodeCoverageExecutionMode":"Always",
"CodeCoverageIncludes":["app.bundle.js"]
}
```

I simply made right click on folder which contains all bundles and perform "Run chutzpahwith>Coverage"

I am using Chtuzpah 4.2.3

title: PhantomJS doesn't support ES6
body:
Current PhantomJS in Chutzpah test running doesn't support ES6 functionality (including simple keywords like "let", "Const" etc.) This has basically rendered use of chutzpah in our project pointless. 

Is there plan to update to latest PhantomJS or instead migrate to GoogleChrome/puppeteer? Is there a fork one is aware of?

title: Version of QUnit is outdated
body:
Hello,

Is it possible for you to update the version of qunit once again to the latest (2.4.0)?
Some major changes to the API were introduced and it would be very helpful if you can do that, so we can benefit from them.

I already did some tests, just replacing the qunit files with the newest ones and everything seem to work without any problems, so it looks compatible (should be a straightforward replacement).

title: Unable to get the jasmine testcase (with for loop) appear using Chutzpah with VS 2013

title: [enhancement] Integrate JS tests with TFS automated functional tests
body:
Yes, you can use UI automation tools like Selenium, but many times they are difficult to maintain and an "under-skin" JS test can do the job (i.e. testing Angular Controllers)

It would be great that we can associate a JavaScript test with a Test Case.

title: chutzpah does not work using typescript with import statements.
[Question] Chutzpah with commonJS module
[Typescript,RequireJS,Jasmine] Jasmine tests are not found
body:
Hello,

first i want to say thanks for this great plugin. I used it with pure JS and i was very satisfied with the results. Now i had to conver my project to TypeScript and i have problems with the correct setup in chutzpah.json.

I'm using VS 2017 15.2 (24630.16), chutzpah 4.3. For compiling i using the VS builtin process with a tsonfig.json file. For some reason the written tests are not found. I tried many configuration variants but with no effort. I created a sample project that have the same problem like my productive project.

The logfile says Message:Unable to build test context.
It would be nice, when you could have a look at settings. The destination path (dist) and all subfolders have to be unchanged. I want the compiled js files in the folder "/dist/source/*. In the folder core are the program files in tests sould be the test files.

Thanks in advance

Sample Project:
[TypeScriptHTMLApp1.zip](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/files/1183093/TypeScriptHTMLApp1.zip)

title: Feature request: Run Chutzpah With => Custom
body:
Maybe it would be possible to add a third option "Custom" in the context menu for running chutzpah.
The command would pass the file path to a script file (e.g. grunt or gulp) that is located in the project.
This way I could use the context menu of chutzpah to run karma tests or whatever I would want
to do with a distinct file. 

(A grunt file with a task for running a single test file with karma can for example be found here:
Maybe it would be possible to add a third option in the context menu for running chutzpah)

Team,
I'm working in SharePoint Office 365 project and I want to do the unit testing with Visual Studio 2015 Enterprise Edition. Can you please share the details how to do that?

Philip

title: Global function no long works?
CLI Lcov coverage when running html runner
body:
Hello,

I'm not 100% sure this is possible.

I'll explain my problem. We currently use QUnit to test our JS, we use individual test runners to do this, with a big "MasterTestRunner" which includes all of our test files and their dependencies.

Currently i'm trying:

`chutzpah.console.exe AlertsTestRunner.html /coverage /lcov cov`

This runs the tests and I get 5 total ran, but the cov file is empty. Now if I point it at the JsTest file, the tests run, but fail (due to it not know what modules are etc) BUT it does give me a populated lcov file. Not 100% sure if it's legit.

Currently our setup is we have a Powershell script that kicks off  node to run node-qunit-phantomjs against our MasterTestRunner. This works brilliantly, runs all the tests and gives us exit codes, but our last piece is to have a lcov file output, which we can then feed in to SonarQube to report on our JS Test coverage.

Basically I'm asking for a bit of help, is this possible? If so could you point me in the right direction please?

Many Thanks,

Iain

title: codecoverageincludes not identifying filename with bootstrap or component
Use of location in code causing file not found in test runner.
body:
Hi,

The following code causes problems when running chutzpah.
`       window.location.href = url;`

This is handled quietly in Reshaper's test runner, but in Chutzpah will cause the page to redirect to a file not found.

I've fixed it in my case by adding a spy on it's containing method and not calling location, this seems like something Chutzpah should be able to handle on our behalf by default, as I can't think of a scenario in which this wouldn't just break things.

title: Inline Reference Path Specification not working
RequireJS config?
body:
Here's my use case:

- TypeScript code in ProjectA
- Grunt/Gulp/WebPack/whatever to build/bundle the code
- Tests in ProjectA.Tests

If I write the tests using TypeScript two things need to work in order for the tests to run.

1. The TypeScript compiler needs to be able to determine types for the  modules I'm testing -  I can work around this by creating declarations and referencing them in tsconfig.json
2. The  testing framework needs to be able to load the modules I'm testing - I can work around this with RequireJS

In order to do this with RequireJS, I need to tweak the configuration. Currently there's no easy way to do that with Chutzpah. I have to create a custom test harness and add the RequireJS reference in there with an appropriate data-main value.

Can we add some of this stuff on the chutzpah.json config file? Either the RequireJs config as an object or maybe a reference to a js file containing the config? Or maybe a value that can be either an object or a string?

Also, on a related note: it would be nice to be able to configure modules to be loaded before the tests. I'm thinking of polyfills and the like.

I hope you are happy to hear from me again (although all I do is open annoying bugs for you :-)).

https://github.com/IsraelHikingMap/Site/
Would appreciate your thoughts.
Keep up the good work!

title: ReferenceError: Strict mode forbids implicit creation of global property '_lodash'
body:
If I attempt to run /coverage I get this error. If I exclude '/coverage' the test passes. The log files for comparison are included. 
[WithCoverage.txt](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/files/956024/WithCoverage.txt)
[NoCoverage.txt](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/files/956025/NoCoverage.txt)

The command I ran (with error):
.\Packages\Chutzpah.4.3.4\tools\chutzpah.console.exe '.\AppLib\AO.Portal.UI.Tests\Modules\AOAdminModule\Views\ResourceSecurityControllerTest .js' /coverage

I found the problem was related to the filename ending in a space. When I removed the space, it functioned as expected. 

While it is technically a bug with coverage, I know the developer did not intend to end the filename in a space and it is something that really shouldn't be done anyway.

VS2015 and Jasmine. If multiple tests and some fail, VS reports 0 tests found
body:
I have a project which has a structure as following:
```
+ Scripts
 + Module01
  - tests.js
 + Module02
  - tests.js
```

Now, if I configure Chutzpah.json as following:

```
  "Tests": [
    {
      "Path": "Scripts",
      "Includes": [ "*/*tests.js" ]
    }
  ]
```

I get back the following:

```
------ Test started: File: C:\DEV\Scripts\Module01\unittests.js, 
C:\DEV\Scripts\Module02\unittests.js ------
========== Total Tests: 0 passed, 0 failed, 0 total ==========

```
So, it finds all my test harnesses but actually it returns 0.
But, if I right click the project and choose "Debug in Browser", then IE opens and I can see Jasmine executing all my tests but some of them are failing:

I also set the tracing but VS 2015 doesn't show anything:

```

  "FrameworkVersion": "2.5.2",
  "EnableTestFileBatching": true,
  "EnableTracing": true,
```

Surely there is something wrong, somewhere but in this way I really can't figure it out.
What am I suppose to do right now in order to understand why Chutzpah can't load my tests?

```powershell
             /MOT:m :: MOnitor source; run again in m minutes Time, if changed.

      /RH:hhmm-hhmm :: Run Hours - times when new copies may be started.

 /XF file [file]... :: eXclude Files matching given names/paths/wildcards.
 /XD dirs [dirs]... :: eXclude Directories matching given names/paths.

::
:: Logging Options :
::
```

title: Cannot get Tests running from TFS 2013 Build
body:
So, I have created 3 different test projects (.dll), each one with its own Chutzpah.json configuration file.
They work just fine locally, I can run **Jasmine**, I can do **Code Coverage** and see the integration with Visual Studio 2015.

Now, I setup my Build Server as explained in the Documentation by following these steps:

1. Configured for the Build Controller a BIN folder using the content of this package: **Chutzpah.4.3.4**
2. Created a Test Settings file which contains the specified XML (see pic)
3. Include the .js and .json file marked as "Content Copy Always"

If I open the **"BIN"** result from TFS and Run Chutzpah via Console or using Visual Studio 2015 (of Build Controller) I can execute the tests.

But if I run the build I get this error, where no tests or test runner compatible were found:

```
Run VS Test Runner00:00:55
Inputs
TestSpecs: BuildParameter[] Array
Enabled: True
ConfigurationsToTest: String[] Array
OutDir:
Test Run Completed. 0 tests executed.
```

So TFS finds the projects specified by my pattern `**\*unittests*.js` but it doesn't understand that they need to be run using Chutzpah.
I am sure 100% sure I am missing something in the configuration of the Build Controller. Maybe I am using wrong version of Chutzpah, I need to install some else?

## Attachments

```
<RunSettings>
  <ChutzpahAdapterSettings>
    <EnabledTracing>true</EnabledTracing>
  </ChutzpahAdapterSettings>

```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1304736/24045767/7e26ffa6-0b20-11e7-87b3-b336da10e173.png)

title: VS2015 Instrumentation error, you cannot redefine the 'window' variable in  file: angular.js
body:
We have a set of Unit Tests built in Jasmine.
The version we are using right now is **2.5.3 of Jasmine**.

If I right click on my test project from **Solution Explorer** and choose "Run JS Tests" I get this output in the Output Window:

```
------ Test started: File: C:\DEV\xxx\unittests.js ------
35 passed, 0 failed, 35 total (chutzpah).

========== Total Tests: 35 passed, 0 failed, 35 total ==========
```

But, if I right click my Tests from **Test Explorer** and choose **Run Selected Tests**, after a while (about 1 minute) I get this error:

```
------ Run test started ------
Error: Error: Instrumentation error, you cannot redefine the 'window' variable in  file:///c:/xxx/angular.js:1876
in file:///C:/xxx/ChutzpahTestHarnessFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 4583)
at forEach  (line 0)
at _checkDefs in file:///C:/xxx/ChutzpahTestHarnessFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 4581)

While Running:c:\xxx\unittests.js

Error: Error: error (timeout=5000) loading source script: file:///c:/xxx/angular.js
in file:///C:/xxx/ChutzpahTestHarnessFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 5476)
While Running:c:\xxx\unittests.js

Error: Timeout occurred when executing test file
While Running:c:\xxx\unittests.js

========== Run test finished: 0 run (0:01:02.6401247) ==========
```

This problem seems to be due to the **Code Coverage** triggered by Test Explorer.
So, I tried to change the Chutzpah.json for the project in this way:

  "CodeCoverageExecutionMode": "Never",

And the tests are running as expected.

## Question
I am aware of the fact that Angular 2.0 has an issue with Phantom, used by Chutzpah, but what about using Istanbul instead? Also, I am on Angular 1.3 but still get the error

body:
This is my `chutzpah.json` configuration:

```json
"References": {
    "https://cdn.polyfill.io/v2/polyfill.min.js"
}
```

I'm using this to polyfill missing ES5-6 objects globally. However, Chutzpah uses a path resolver internally that is incompatible with such a URL, and the following stack trace is generated:

```

   a következő helyen: Chutzpah.TestRunner.<>c__DisplayClass37_0.<BuildTestRunConfiguration>b__0(PathInfo path) hely: C:\Dev\chutzpah\Chutzpah\TestRunner.cs, sor: 327
   a következő helyen: System.Linq.Enumerable.WhereSelectListIterator`2.MoveNext()
   a következő helyen: System.Linq.Lookup`2.Create[TSource](IEnumerable`1 source, Func`2 keySelector, Func`2 elementSelector, IEqualityComparer`1 comparer)
```

The stack-trace is reported in Hungarian, but I believe it is absolutely clear what's going on. If I download the polyfill manually and feed the resulting `.js` file into Chutzpah, it's running flawlessly.

I'm not sure if you intend on providing support for such, presumably rare use cases, but if so, this could be a starting point. Thanks again for authoring Chutzpah, it's a huge productivity booster.

title: Code Coverage exclude breaking tests with AngularJS injection
body:
All of our tests pass for this AngularJS application, with code coverage enabled.  However, there are some extra files that we don't want coverage reported on, and when we specify these in the CodeCoverageExcludes block, our tests start failing, due to missing Angular dependencies.
I suspect the coverage engine is getting confused because of our slightly whacky file layout (changing file hierarchy isn't much of an option right now);  all of our tests are under a JSTests (but yes, we've actually converted to TypeScript) folder in our web project, sibling to our app/ folder where our code is.  Under the JSTests folder are our spec files in subfolders, AND we have some test helper files under there too.  There are two subfolders mocks and ngTestDoubles.  The mocks folder just contains simple classes with static methods (thus, they're never utiilzed by Angular dependency injection), while the ngTestDoubles has some "replacement" constant and value classes (that are usually dynamically loaded at runtime).  So we wind up seeing code coverage of these ngTestDoubles files, which I want to exclude from the report.
However, excluding these files via the CodeCoverageExcludes setting *seems* to cause the files to no longer be loaded in *at all*, resulting in AngularJS throwing exceptions on nearly every test because of missing dependencies.

title: Add support for QUnit 2.0
body: This has breaking changes so needs to initially be optional then become default in the next major release

title: Add support for proxy servers
body:
I have been struggled in trying to get Chutzpah working for a couple of days, and in the end, I found that the issue is due to the fact that it doesn't support proxy. the Unit test i am trying to test has a external reference to a cdn url, obviously it stop the test runner from discover the test or run the test, with error like "connection timeout". I have a look at the source code, and notice that the proxy server setting is disabled.
Can a option be provided to allow turn the proxy setting on? and allow to pass in the proxy server/port from json config file? Thanks

title: No Tests will be shown
FileNotFoundException with different working directory and TestFiles folder
body:
I am running chutzpah on our CCNet CI using the console runner but I've also discovered this issue locally: If you run chutzpah.console.exe from a different working directory it will fail to run the tests since it cannot find the neccessary chutzpah dependencies. 
```
C:\Dev\MyQUnitProject>C:\Tools\chutzpah\chutzpah.console.exe . 
Chutzpah console test runner  (64-bit .NET 4.0.30319.42000)
Version 4.3.3.0
Copyright (C) 2016 Matthew Manela (http://matthewmanela.com).

Error: System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not find file 'C:\Dev\MyQUnitProject\chutzpah_boot.js'.
File name: 'C:\Dev\MyQUnitProject\chutzpah_boot.js'
   at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError(Int32 errorCode, String maybeFullPath)
```

First I thought it might be a general issue that it looks for the chutzpah_boot.js within the working directory. But the problem seems to be caused by the `TestFiles` folder. For my own test files i have a `TestFiles` directory in my test project. It seems that this misleads chutzpah to think it needs to look for the chutzpah_boot.js in the working directory. I found the cause in the code:  https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/blob/3a54a62f6218fd5e789781c4ad57693d6e657027/Chutzpah/FileProbe.cs#L223 

I think the exe path should overrule the working directory by default. Or at least the `BuiltInDependencyDirectory` should not only look for the `TestFiles` folder, but also for some chutzpah specific file. `TestFiles` is quite a general name that might exist in your test project. 

So a simple alternative could also be to rename `TestFiles` to `ChutzpahTestFiles` or `TestRuntime` to remove this ambiguous naming.

title: Error 404 for unknown file types
body:
I loading certain test data via AJAX from a test files directory. In general this works fine as long I use the server mode. But it seems for all file types that are not known to the system, the web server returns an error 404.  

For example: If you have a .txt file, it is properly provided via the HTTP server and therefore also via Ajax. But if you have an unknown file type like .abc or .xyz the server always returns error 404 even though the file is on the file system. This is a bit annoying since I now need to rename all my test files to something like .txt to get them in my tests.

 This error happens in both the VS Test Explorer extension and the console runner of the latest released version 4.3.3.

title: No tests found
body:
I have an odd issue that I am looking for any advice on.

I am running Chutzpah 4.3.3 and have Jasmine 2.5.2 installed. I wrote a bunch of unit tests in Jasmine months ago and was able to run them fine with Chutzpah then (including code coverage). I have not run these tests in a few months not but needed to update some of them so I tried running them again yesterday and nothing happens. When I use Chutzpah to run the tests (any of them) it just shows "0 passed, 0 failed, 0 total".

The important thing to note here is that nothing has really changed. We didn't update or change anything besides some code files in our project. It is possible that Chutzpah updated since the last time I ran them since it is set to automatically update. I did manually update Jasmine in case that was the issue but that doesn't appear to have helped.

My Chutzpah config is pretty simple and hasn't changed:
```
{
  "Framework": "jasmine",
  "RootReferencePathMode":  "SettingsFileDirectory", 
  "EnableCodeCoverage ": "false",
  "CodeCoverageIncludes": [
    "*/App/Controllers/*.js",
    "*/App/Directives/*.js",
    "*/App/Service/*.js",
    "*/App/*.js",
    "*.spec.js"
  ],
  "CodeCoverageExcludes": [
    "*/scripts/*.*",
    "*/templates/*.html"
  ],
  "TestFileTimeout":200000
}
```
I set reference paths directly in each of my spec files. I have like 20 spec files and this was all working fine previously. I can't figure out why it suddenly isn't finding my tests. The spec files have no changed since the last time I ran them.

title: Running chutzpah.console.exe Fails w/ TypeInitializationException b/c Unable to load libuv.dll
body:
Running Chutzpah from command line on a 64-bit machine:
`..\packages\Chutzpah.4.3.3\tools\chutzpah.console.exe /path .`

Fails:

```
Chutzpah console test runner  (64-bit .NET 4.0.30319.42000)
Version 4.3.3.0
Copyright (C) 2016 Matthew Manela (http://matthewmanela.com).
System.TypeInitializationException: The type initializer for 'Chutzpah.ChutzpahContainer' threw an exception. ---> Chutzpah.Exceptions.ChutzpahException: Unable to load libuv.dll
   at Chutzpah.ChutzpahContainer..cctor()
   --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
   at Chutzpah.ChutzpahContainer.get_Current()
   at Chutzpah.TestRunner.Create(Boolean debugEnabled)
   at Chutzpah.Program.RunTests(CommandLine commandLine, IEnumerable`1 transformers)
   at Chutzpah.Program.Main(String[] args)
```

This is apparently due to bitness of `libuv.dll`. This can be worked around by doing a `corflags chutzpah.console.exe /32bitreq+`, but it is clunky and the Chutzpah compile should likely be updated to reflect bitness requirement of dependencies.

title: Q: Is code-coverage supported through VSTS integrated builds?
body:
*This is an awesome extension and I'm so thankful you put effort and time into working on it. I have a small **question** though.*

I'm running the latest Chutzpah release both in my Visual Studio 2015 and our integrated online build through VSTS (Visual Studio Team Services). The tests run correctly in both places, every single one of our tests pass, the outcome is identical and the test duration is comparable.

**Code coverage**

When running Chutzpah with code-coverage, *inside Visual Studio*, the HTML report opens showing the covered files, their code coverage results, as well as the average code coverage, which is **68%**, with **4499 total statements** detected. So far so good.

**Different results in VSTS build**

However, when the tests run *through VS Team Services*, I'm getting _entirely_ different reports. The code coverage reports **5 683/18 075 blocks** (~31%) and **3 459/13 535** lines (~26%). Now these are obviously wrong, as there aren't even as many lines in the covered files.

-----

My question is: does Chutzpah _not_ support integrated builds, or am I doing something wrong? On the VSTS integrated build, I have enabled the code-coverage setting.

This is the relevant part of my configuration:

```json
{
    "CodeCoverageExecutionMode": "Always",
    "CodeCoverageIncludes": [
        "_references/*.js"
    ],
    "CodeCoverageExcludes": [
        "**.tests.js",
        "**.tests.ts"
    ],
    "EnableCodeCoverage": true
}
```

And this is the command executed by the VSTS build (edited for clarity):

```
vstest.console.exe "testfile.tests.js" /Settings:"255.tmp" /EnableCodeCoverage /logger:trx /TestAdapterPath:"packages"
```

So the command certainly goes through, but the coverage that comes back is almost certainly incorrect.

title: Global Error
how to define requireJS paths for 3rd party libraries?
body:
Hi @mmanela 

I just finished moving my source over to use requireJS, so now I have to move my tests to use requireJS too. I got this working in a simple sample project first and I have Chutzpah performing brilliantly there. 

However, in my real project I quickly ran into a snag. How do I define the path to the third party  libraries that my code is "requiring"? 

For instance, in my typescript code that requires moment.js, I would do this at the top of the file:

import moment = require('moment');

Then in a js file I configure requireJS to know where moment is located: 
```
requirejs.config({
    baseUrl: 'Scripts',
    paths: {
        "jquery": "libs/jquery-3.1.1",
        "moment": "libs/moment",
    },
});
```

I don't see anything in the documentation of where to put this type of configuration for Chutzpah. And if I define a JS file with this requirejs.config in it, then everything breaks. 

Right now I am working around it by using the References section of the Chutzpah.json file:

```
  "References": [
    {
      "Path": "../squashspider/scripts/jquery-1.10.2.js",
      "IsTestFrameworkFile": true
    },
```

But that is not ideal because this kills my ability to ensure that I am requiring the right package dependencies in my code. 

Is there a way to inject these requireJS path definitions?

Thanks
Greg

title: No coverage generated using SystemJS + import statements
Unit tests in same VS project as source (using TS, AMD) Test Explorer empty
body:
Hi @mmanela 

summary: had to move my TS unit tests into my main script directory and main project. Now the test explorer is empty


I have been using Chutzpah for a while with my project successfully. However, the project is getting to a size where I want to move away from using TS's reference directives to using requireJS to load modules. With my successfully running project, I have two projects in my solution: the main product and a TS unit test project. Chutzpah correctly fills in the Test Explorer window with the 500+ unit tests we have and life is good. I just got these unit tests running on our CI server on Visual Studio Online. 

Now that I am moving to using requireJS and proper modules, I decided to create a test project where I am trying to get everything working first. The first stumbling block was that I couldn't get the TS compiler to find modules defined in the main project from the unit test project. This turns out to be a known limitation of VS. There are a couple solutions out there, but i couldn't get them to work. So I started looking at your samples in Chutzpah and decided that I would bite the bullet and move my unit tests into the main project. I know have a Scripts directory structure that looks like this: (BTW, this is an ASP.Net MVC/WebApi app). 

```
Scripts
-> Chutzpah.json
-> config.ts     // require.js configuration-> Api  // the TS files for using the Api methods
-> App           // the TS files that make up the main application
-> libs          // the JS files I import
-> Typings       // .d.ts files
-> Tests         // The tests live under this directory
    --> Api      // test files for testing the Api TS files
    --> App      // test files for testing the App TS files
```

I have successfully setup the test app so that the TS files are properly loaded by the browser and execute properly. 

I have successfully setup Chutzpah such that I can right click a TS file in the Tests directory and select Run JS Tests and the tests will run. I get the output in the console that says how many tests were run. 
I can run any single TS test in the browser and it properly loads the required modules using require.js and the tests pass. 

Where things are falling down if I do a ctrl-r, a, then nothing runs. It does a build but no tests are found. And at no point have I seen any of the tests show up in the test explorer. My Chutzpah.json is as follows:

```
{
  "Framework": "jasmine",
  "TestHarnessReferenceMode": "AMD",
  "TestHarnessLocationMode": "SettingsFileAdjacent",
  "EnableTestFileBatching": true,
  "AMDBaseUrl": "",

    {
      "Path": "require.js",
      "IsTestFrameworkFile": true
    },
    {
      "Path": "config.js", 
      "IsTestFrameworkFile": true
    }
  ],
  "Tests": [
    {
      "Path": "Tests",
      "Includes": [ "*/Tests/*.ts" ],
      "Excludes": [ "*/Tests/*.d.ts" ]
    }
  ]
}
```

Is having Chutzpah run in the main project within the solution a problem? (in this simple test app this is the only project in the solution). 

Thanks
Greg

title: polymer+PhantomJS
body:
Hi Matthew. 
I tests my webcomponets that uses polymer library. But chutzpah uses PhantomJS and my tests are failed. 


Libraries/Tools 

The headless browser Chutzpah uses is called PhantomJS. PhantomJS is based on the webkit rendering engine which is important to keep in mind since you are not guaranteed your tests will pass on a browser that uses a different rendering engine. However, in most cases your tests should work fine in across most the modern browser. **In the future Chutzpah will support more browsers that use different rendering engines.** 
Last edited Jun 20, 2011 at 1:27 AM by mmanela, version 3 

Should we wait for support more browsers and if yes then when? 
Thnx

title: Error: Line 42: Unexpected token (
body:
Hi @mmanela 

I built a custom VSTS build step based on Chutzpah. During our automated builds I wanted not only to run the Jasmine tests we had, but also establish the code coverage and fail a build if coverage drops below a threshold set by the team.

This was working for a few weeks. We are using the /coverage flag on the command line.

Now, even in VS on a dev machine using the Chutzpah plugins we see lots of timeouts. Increasing the time out to"TestFileTimeout": 200000 in the chutzpah.json file does not improve this.

I checked out the git repo for Chutzpah to see if I could see what was going wrong.

I thought I tracked it down to blanket_jasmine_v2.js ~ line 5473

var timeout = _blanket.options("timeout") || 3000;

I tried overriding this and manually setting the timeout to 200000 also. 

var timeout = _blanket.options("timeout") || 3000;
timeout = 200000;

The error message being reported was being generated just beneath by

`throw new Error("error (timeout=" + timeout + ") loading source script: " + options.url);`

But the timeout was reported as 180, not 200000 or 3000. I might be getting my timeouts muddled up, so please bear with me.

If I turn coverage off, everything works again. It doesn't seem intermittent, every test run now has timeout issues. This used to work just fine on my project so I am not ruling out a problem in either our JS or our Jasmine tests. Line 42: Unexpected token (

I don't know which file it it referring to, so its hard to figure it out.

Any ideas?

Cheers,
Ian

Every test errors out with the following error:
https://s14.postimg.org/g4opp6ajl/Chutzpah_Errors.png

I've looked at related issues and it seems like it was due to bugs within VS' testing framework itself. I believe the version I'm running is the latest. Older versions also result in these errors.

Thanks!

title: FormData support

title: Fix AmdFilePath when path contains file extension

AmdPath was incorrect.

This commit will make sure only the file extension is removed when
setting AmdFilePath.

body:

I have app written using VS Code and nodejs. There is no .sln file.  I've added nuget.config and packages.config to my root folder and installed the nuget package. On the buils server there is nuget restore build step and the packages are restored, however the test adapter is not recognized.

When I try it locally on my dev machine, the test adapter are not recognized either:

```
>"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\Common7\IDE\CommonExtensions\Microsoft\TestWindow\vstest.console.exe" /TestAdapterPath:"C:\Temp\unit testing\Packages\"
Microsoft (R) Test Execution Command Line Tool Version 14.0.25123.0
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation.  All rights reserved.

Warning: The path 'C:\Temp\unit testing\Packages\' specified in the 'TestAdapterPath' does not contain any test adapters, provide a valid path and try again.
```

title: multi-file source isn't working for me
body:
Hi

I have a problem where, when I try to run a test, I get a ReferenceError: Can't find variable: KnockoutCourt. This is one of my typescript classes. 

I think I am missing some high level knowledge about how to set this up. So please indulge me as I try to describe my setup from the top. 

I am trying to test a ViewModel class for a page that uses knockout. The page loads data from a WebService written in C#. I am using an excellent tool called typewriter that will turn C# model/view model definitions into typescript files. I then include them on the page and I have easy access to the webservice. 

What this does, is it creates a number of files though. So my file structure looks like this: (and this is the order that I include them on my html page)

ApiCourtGroupsViewModel.ts
ApiCourtsViewModel.ts
CourtGroupsController.ts

of course I include the .js files in the html file. 

I then include:
messenger.js (for page level alerts)
CourtGroups.ts

It is CourtGroups.ts that is my typescript viewmodel that I want to test. 

My first question:
Do I have to include "References" to the first three files (ApiCourtGroupsViewModel.ts, ApiCourtsViewModel.ts and CourtGroupsController.ts) in my Chutzpah.json file? 

Do I need to have CourtGroups.ts included in the reference section of the Chutzpah.json file?

Oh, these files also reference Knockout since a bunch of the variables are knockout observables. So do I need to include knockout in the reference section of my Chutzpah.json file? 

Each time I add a new file like CourtGroups.ts, it is going to have an accompanying few .ts files in this similar structure. Am I going to have to add all of these to the Chutzpah.json file each time I want to test this new typescript viewmodel file? 

I think I need to see the answer to these questions before I proceed with asking my next question. Because right now I have all of these in my Chutzpah.json file and I am getting this ReferenceError when I try to run a simple unit test (jasmine). It says it cant find a variable that is a class defined in ApiCourtsViewModel.ts.

BTW, all of these files are embedded in a namespace of Api.Courtbooking. I was wondering if that is screwing it up. All this works fine on the applications page, I am just coming back to it to setup unit testing. 

Here is what my current Chutzpah.json file looks like:

```
{
  "Compile": {
    "Mode": "External",
    "Extensions": [ ".ts" ],
    "ExtensionsWithNoOutput": [ ".d.ts" ],
    "UseSourceMaps": true
  },
  "References": [
    { "Path": "../scripts/knockout-3.4.0.js", "IsTestFrameworkFile": true },
    { "Path": "../Scripts/App/CourtBooking/ApiCourtGroupsViewModel.ts" },
    { "Path": "../Scripts/App/CourtBooking/ApiCourtsViewModel.ts" },
    { "Path": "../Scripts/App/CourtBooking/CourtGroupsController.ts" },
    {
      "Path": "../Scripts/App/CourtBooking/CourtGroups.js"
    }
  ],
  "Tests": [
    {
      "Includes": [ "*/Scripts/*.ts" ],
      "Excludes": [ "*/Scripts/*.d.ts" ]
    }
  ],
  "CodeCoverageExecutionMode": "Always",
  "CodeCoverageIncludes": [
    "../Scripts/App/CourtGroups.*"
  ]
}


```

I am not sure if I got it right.

thanks
Greg

title: Chutzpah Visual Studio test runner failing tests that pass in browser/ReSharper
TFS Build with Typescript, chutzpah.json, AMD, requirejs
body:
Hello,

First off, Chutzpah is awesome. We used it in our Javascript app with TFS and everything worked wonderfully. Really impressive.

Unfortunately, I haven't been able to get it to work in our new Typescript project. We have a TypeScript app that uses jspm for package management and transpiles all the TS to systemjs. For what it's worth, I originally tried to get Chutzpah to work with systemjs and combed through [this issue](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/issues/534) , but couldn't get that working quite right either, so I decided to add an extra gulp task and transpile all of our TypeScript into AMD modules that requirejs can use and got Chutzpah to work great with some tweaks to the chutzpah.json file when running from Visual Studio. This is our current chutzpah.json file:

```
{
  "Framework": "jasmine",
  "TestHarnessReferenceMode": "AMD",
  "TestHarnessLocationMode": "SettingsFileAdjacent",
  "EnableTestFileBatching": true,
  "AMDBaseUrl": "Tests/", 
  "AMDAppDirectory": "App/", 
  "Compile": {
    "Mode": "External"
  },
  "References": [
    {
      "Path": "tests/vendor/require.js",
      "IsTestFrameworkFile": true
    },
    {
      "Path": "tests/vendor/config.js"
    }
  ],
  "Tests": [
    {
      "Path": "App/",
      "Includes": [ "*.spec.ts" ]
    }
  ]
}
```

Now, I'm trying to get our gated check-in to run the Jasmine tests. I think I've poured over every blog post & thread here and haven't found a working solution. In Summary, here's what I have tried so far:
- Copied the latest Chutzpah.vsix contents to our build controller's custom assemblies directories
- Installed Chutzpah Nuget Package to the project
- Added custom Pre-Build task to the project that Transpiles all of the TS into AMD javascript into the AMDBaseUrl (Tests/) directory, then copies the entire App and Tests directories to the Output Directory used by the build
- Specified custom runSettings.xml file with: 
    TestingMode = All
   EnabledTracing = true
  This causes the build to at least acknowledge that the chutzpah.json file is present. But this is the only thing that gets logged to the %temp% log file:
  Chutzpah.json file found at D:\Builds\9386...\bin\chutzpah.json given starting directory D:\Builds\9386...\bin
- I logged into the build server's source directory where it copies all of the files to before building, and manually ran chutzpah.console.exe from the packages folder with the path to the chutzpah.json file, and it's able to run the all the tests without any issues. I noticed that none of the chutzpah Nuget dlls are copied to the bin folder where TFS compiles the project into. Should they? 

Any help would be so greatly appreciated. Thank you!

title: Test discoverer reports "cannot find path" errors for large test files with many ajax calls
body:
We have a large project with many test files. These test files test methods and objects that make use of many $.getJSON and $.ajax calls. When a test file grows to a certain size, these ajax calls start to report errors in the output window e.g.:

Error: Error: Error opening /Controller/SomeMethodName: The system cannot find the path specified.
While Running:C:\test-file.ts

This is reported during test discovery after making a change to a test file.

We've found that by breaking these large test files down into smaller test files, this temporarily fixes the problem, however as those test files grow, the error returns.

This error doesn't prevent Visual Studio Test Explorer from being able to run the tests, however, since they are reported on TFS as well, they do prevent the Test build step from completing.

NB: We are using the jasmine testing framework.

body:
Using VS 2015 Professional Update 3, Chutzpan Test Runner Context Menu 4.2.3

Intermittently I am having the following issue: 
When using the menu command

> Run JS Tests

on a folder containing all my tests, some tests may run and then the remaining tests report the following message, or all tests report the following message:

> `Error: Timeout occurred when executing test file`

If I then chose an individual file and use the menu command

> Open In Browser

that individual test file is executed correctly.
If I return to using

> Run JS Tests

The timeouts may go away by restarting VS or rebooting the OS, but not consistently.

I installed a separate installation using chocolatey. 
Created a dummy test file that contains only

> `console.log("I was executed");`

and is outside any VS solution, I executed with

> chutzpah.console.exe .\dummyTest.js /debug

which results in the following

> Chutzpah console test runner  (64-bit .NET 4.0.30319.42000)
> Version 4.2.3.0
> Copyright (C) 2015 Matthew Manela (http://matthewmanela.com).
> 
> Error: Timeout occurred when executing test file
> While Running:F:\dummyTest.js
> 
> === 0 total, 0 failed, took 15.06 seconds ===

Any suggestions as to what I can do to narrow down what is causing the timeouts.

Regards

Aidan

title: Coverage of .js files containing arrow functions ( => )
body:
Hi Matthew,

Not entirely sure if this falls under your project, given it seems to be a blanket.js issue but...

When code coverage includes a file for coverage featuring an arrow function then blanket_jasmine_v2.js throws an "unexpected token" error when parsing the ">".

My particular stack trace begins:

`Error:Error: Line 46: Unexpected token >
at throwError in file:///C:/Program%20Files/chutzpah/TestFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 1171)
at throwUnexpected in file:///C:/Program%20Files/chutzpah/TestFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 1217)
at parsePrimaryExpression in file:///C:/Program%20Files/chutzpah/TestFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 1563)
in file:///C:/Program%20Files/chutzpah/TestFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 3600)
at trackLeftHandSideExpressionAllowCall in file:///C:/Program%20Files/chutzpah/TestFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 3495)
at parsePostfixExpression in file:///C:/Program%20Files/chutzpah/TestFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 1699)
in file:///C:/Program%20Files/chutzpah/TestFiles/Coverage/blanket_jasmine_v2.js (line 3600)`
...

Where line 46 happens to be a line in one of my application files using an arrow function. If I comment that line out, the line error changes to 50, where the second and last arrow function is. Commenting both out means the coverage runs. The two troublesome lines in my application are:

`Line 46: var productRoleId = vm.roleTypes.findIndex((el) => el.roleId === roleId);`
`Line 50: var index = vm.rolesToUpdate.findIndex((el) => el.Hash === userId + roleId);`

I'm currently working around this using the "CodeCoverageExcludes" option in chutzpah.json, but would like to know if there's anyway I'll be able to run coverage on code containing this syntax in the future.

Thanks in advance,
Chris.

title: Lcov file is created empty
body:
Hi,

I'm using the console runner to run my typescript tests.
The tests runs locally just fine from visual studio and I even get the nice html coverage report.
Now I want to publish this report to coveralls.io.
I know that coveralls doesn't support the format chutzpah writes but I found a way to convert the lcov file to what coveralls process.
unfortunately I can't get the lcov file to have any data in it when running from command line:
`chutzpah.console.exe .\chutzpah.json /converage /lcov .\chutzpah-results-lcov.xml`
am I doing something wrong?
Also tried junit, but got only tests report without coverage:
`chutzpah.console.exe .\chutzpah.json /converage /junit .\chutzpah-results-junit.xml`
Tried coveragejson flag which didn't create a file (I believe that when a user adds the /coveragejson flag it means he wants to get coverage report...)

This is the only thing that created a report file, I'm still trying to figure out how to read it:

title: Fix #540 - coverage + source maps with spaces in path causes NaN for coverage values
body: Daft issue where I was comparing a URL-encoded path to a non-URL-encoded path, leading to spaces being %20 in one side of the comparison and a straight space in the other. Fixed by normalising to URIs in both cases and doing the comparison that way, appears to resolve issue #540.

Visual Studio Contradiction
body:
I posted [my problem on StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/q/38491238/1680677), but I'm hoping you can offer some insight. I can try putting together a repro if you need one, but the major details are in the post, so hopefully that can get us a little way on it's own.

In summary, Chutzpah works for a simple JavaScript test, but all my AngularJS tests (using the Jasmine) fail. It's as if the dependencies aren't fully defined, and I'm not sure why. Visual Studio seems split between it's Locals tab saying the dependencies are fully defined and the Watch tab saying properties are undefined.

title: Visual Studio 2015 Update 3
body:
IDE: **Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2015, Version 14.0.25420.01 Update 3**

There seems to be an issue with `Chutzpah`. When I have the `Chutzpah Test Adapter for Test Explorer` enabled, **Visual Studio** becomes unresponsive and only "Tests" output, in the `Output Window` are available as it is so busy trying to "discover" tests. It might be related to this [open issue](https://github.com/aspnet/Tooling/issues/604#issuecomment-229097213). It immediately re-attempts to discover them again after it fails with the following message:

> '1.0.0-*' is not a valid version string.
> Parameter name: value

The process simply gets bogged down and after enough time, the **IDE** is so sluggish that you need to kill in from _Task Manager_. It took me a while, but I have isolated the issue to this current install of the **IDE** and `Chutzpah Test Adapter for Test Explorer, version 4.2.3`. When I disable that extension the symptom goes away. There is no longer an infinite loop and the **IDE** is responsive but there is still the error mentioned above.

If I use mstest to run .NET tests and generate a TRX file, any ignored tests are not reported in the TRX file, but are listed as warnings in the console output:

```
Starting execution...
Warning: The disabled test 'IgnoredTest' was removed from the test run.
```

title: Test output file shows 0 tests when using openInBrowser
body:
If I run:

```
PS C:\Thing> .\packages\Chutzpah.4.2.1\tools\chutzpah.console.exe "$testFile" /failOnError
/nunit2 "TestResults\$name.xml"
```

Then I get a test results file as expected. However, if I try running in a browser:

```
PS C:\Thing> .\packages\Chutzpah.4.2.1\tools\chutzpah.console.exe "$testFile" /failOnError
/nunit2 "TestResults\$name.xml" /openInBrowser chrome
```

Now I get an output file that says 0 tests were run:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="us-ascii"?>
<test-results name="Chutzpah Test Results" total="0" errors="0" failures="0" not-run="0" inconclusive="0" ignored="0" skipped="0" invalid="0" date="2016-05-23" time="16:21:41" />
```

I can't find any info on whether this is intended to be supported. Is the a mechanism to report the tests back from the browser to the process? (If not, is it worth adding a warning if you use `openInBrowser` and an output flag?)

title: Tests not found: Total Tests: 0 passed, 0 failed, 0 total
Detecting Tests outside of configured test paths + angular not found
Having the chutzpah test adapter active keeps open handles to target files
body:
I'm still trying to debug exactly what's going on here, but I noticed the issue dissipate when I disabled the Chutzpah VS Test Adapter extension (along with VS2015 Update 2). 

My team uses a standard gulp workflow to build files into an output directory (i.e. dist), and chutzpah.json to set references and test locations. However, our clean step frequently fails if a developer is using visual studio + chutzpah test adapter plugin, and running handle on our dist/ folder shows pretty much every referenced file as being open by visual studio. After disabling the Chutzpah plugin, this behavior dissipates.

Is there any way to prevent this aggressive locking behavior? 

Also, any recommendations you have for the traditional gulp/grunt flows would be helpful-- Running tests out of our output folder and cleaning the output folder every time we build is the standard practice.

body: Hi, I am using Chutzpah on my dev machine as well as during our TFS nightly builds. The builds were running fine, with code coverage as well, but at some point started showing the issue mentioned in [#340](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/issues/340) and [#493](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/issues/493). I upgraded the Chutzpah files for the build server reference assemblies, as reccomended in one of those issues, to the latest version (4.2.1), and I think I also made some changes to the projects chutzpah.json files too. TFS build now no longer runs js tests, and for each js file gives the following exception in TFS build log: Error: System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object. at Chutzpah.TestHarness.BuildTags(IEnumerable`1 referencedFilePaths) at Chutzpah.TestHarness..ctor(ChutzpahTestSettingsFile chutzpahTestSettings, TestOptions testOptions, IEnumerable "1 referencedFiles, IFileSystemWrapper fileSystem) at Chutzpah.TestHarnessBuilder.CreateTestHarness(TestContext testContext, TestOptions options) at Chutzpah.TestRunner.c__DisplayClass15.b__14(TestContext testContext) Providing a repo to replicate this may be difficult, since the tests run fine in VS 2015 and only appear on TFS tests. But I can run builds anytime manually and provide any of our config/code files to help resolve this issue.

title: Code coverage using sourcemaps does not apply to asynchronously loaded files.
body:
Hi,

I am using chutzpah for my typescript project, and recently added coverage.
I use requirejs, jasmine, external (Visual Studio) compilation, and "UseSourceMaps" option is set to true in my chutzpah.json file. I have been unable so far to get coverage for the source _.ts_ files, I get it only for the generated _.js_ files (ie the coverage html file mentions only _.js_ files).

I had a look at [this issue](https://github.com/mmanela/chutzpah/issues/308) and the associated (wonderful) PR, and it seems to me that me mapping between generated and source files is done only for "referenced files", which asynchronously loaded files are not. From my understanding, the mapping is reused to decide whether a coverage result for a javascript file should be remapped to the source file once coverage is done.

I created this small project for easier reproduction, this should make it easier for you to tell me if I missed something : 
https://github.com/dufrannea/ChutzpahTypescriptCoverage

I tested with [those changes](https://github.com/dufrannea/chutzpah/commit/f988e73f5978209dcda7c60c39b743c463c537c2) and I properly get coverage for my typescript source files. What my changes do is to  opportunistically find sources and source maps once coverage is done. The way to identify sources is clearly not how it should be done, but hopefully it illustrates my point.

Can you tell me if I am missing something here ? 

Cheers !

title: Chutzpah cannot run tests in Travis CI
body:
When I try to run Chutzpah javascript tests on Travis CI, I get the following output:

```
$ mono ./packages/Chutzpah.4.2.1/tools/chutzpah.console.exe ./Tests/Unit/Scripts
Chutzpah console test runner  (64-bit .NET 4.0.30319.17020)
Version 4.2.1.0
Copyright (C) 2015 Matthew Manela (http://matthewmanela.com).
.IO.FileNotFoundException: Unable to find test runner base js file: JSRunners\chutzpahRunner.js
  at Chutzpah.TestRunner.ProcessTestPaths (IEnumerable`1 testPaths, Chutzpah.TestOptions options, TestExecutionMode testExecutionMode, ITestMethodRunnerCallback callback) <0x4196de30 + 0x0086e> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Chutzpah.TestRunner.RunTests (IEnumerable`1 testPaths, Chutzpah.TestOptions options, ITestMethodRunnerCallback callback) <0x4196dc90 + 0x00077> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Chutzpah.Program.RunTests (Chutzpah.CommandLine commandLine) <0x41911810 + 0x00ad8> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Chutzpah.Program.Main (System.String[] args) <0x4190bd80 + 0x00162> in <filename unknown>:0 
The command "mono ./packages/Chutzpah.4.2.1/tools/chutzpah.console.exe ./Tests/Unit/Scripts" exited with 1.
```

However, if I run the same command-line argument on my local machine, the tests run fine.  I am not sure what is different about the Travis CI environment that causes it to not find the `chutzpahRunner.js` file.

Here is my `.travis.yml`:

```
language: csharp
solution: DNDGenSite.sln
install:
  - nuget restore DNDGenSite.sln
  - nuget install NUnit.Runners -OutputDirectory testrunner
script:
  - xbuild DNDGenSite.sln /p:TargetFrameworkVersion="v4.5.1" /p:Configuration=Release
  - mono ./testrunner/NUnit.ConsoleRunner.*/tools/nunit3-console.exe ./Tests/bin/Release/DNDGenSite.Tests.dll
  - mono ./packages/Chutzpah.4.2.1/tools/chutzpah.console.exe ./Tests/Unit/Scripts
```

I will say, I recently encountered an issue with NUnit where referencing properties on a dynamic object was fine locally, but threw a hissy-fit on Travis CI, and so I had to find a way around that (referencing a different pointer that was not a property on the dynamic object).  I wonder if something similar is occurring within the Chutzpah codebase...
