title: Coverage + QUnit + Require.js results in timeout
body:
JustinCredible[CodePlex]
I've been able to setup QUnit testing and coverage using Chutzpah without require.js and everything works fine from both the Visual Studio extensions as well as the console runner. Next, I added require.js into the mix. The tests work fine from both Visual Studio extensions and the console runner. Coverage, however, does not. It always results in a timeout. I am not using a custom harness template. I was able to put together a sample project that illustrates the issue. If you open the attached VS solution you'll see that the test run works fine, but coverage does not. I've done a bit of debugging by capturing the Chutzpah HTML harness that is output and running it in my browser. In the console I can see that the wrong URL is being used to load the test file. I left the generated harness in the ZIP file (as _Chutzpah.fee23f2ac30325a47f946e34b7df81eb.test.html) so it can be examined. Basically it is trying to load a URL that has repeated quot/Tests/quot in the path: ltRootgt/WebApplication3/Tests/Tests/Modules/ExampleTests.js instead of what it should actually be loading: ltRootgt/WebApplication3/Tests/Modules/ExampleTests.js Perhaps the require.js options are modified differently by Chutzpah during a coverage test?

title: timeout executing test file for template html partial
body:
marfarma[CodePlex]
I get the following error for each of my project's view partials when opening my solution in VS2012: ------ Discover test started ------ NUnit 1.0.0.0 discovering tests is started NUnit 1.0.0.0 discovering test is finished Error: Timeout occured when executing test file While Running:c:[...]\solutionName\projectName\templates\tradelist.html [...] ========== Discover test finished: 139 found (0:00:21.7352432) ========== When Chutzpah is disabled, the errors are not reported. The only reference I could find in the documentation on specifying the inclusion or exclusion of files referred to including / excluding javaScript code, not html files. However, adding the following to my config file fixed the errors. ``` quotTestHarnessLocationModequot: quotCustomquot, quotTestHarnessDirectoryquot: quotContent\js\testsquot, quotRootReferencePathModequot:quotSettingsFileDirectoryquot, quotTestsquot: [ { quotPathquot: quotContent\js\testsquot, quotIncludequot: quot*Spec.jsquot} ] ``` OK. But why was Chutzpah attempted to run my view partials as tests? Did it think they were test harness pages? I'd previously had the quotTestHarnessLocationModequot as quotTestFileAdjacentquot -- there are no javascript files in the templates directory, so they should have been ignored.

title: Mocha + angular-mocks incompatibility
body:
jyboudreau[CodePlex]
There is an issue in the test harness when using mocha and angular-mocks together. Angular mocks uses the beforeEach and afterEach method of mocha (and jasmine) to setup some stuff. The problem is the order of operation in the test harness: pseudo-code lt!-- Included by Chutzpah automatically--gt ltscript src=quotmocha.jsquotgt ... lt!-- Included by Chutzpah from the Chutzpah.json references --gt ltscript src=quotangular-mocks.jsquotgt ... lt!-- Included by Chutzpah automatically--gt ltscriptgt mocha.setup('bdd'); lt/scriptgt The problem is that the beforeEach method is not defined until the mocha.setup is called. Suggest moving the mocha.setup right below the inclusion of mocha.js.

title: Generate code coverage in LCOV format within TFS build
body:
ycrumeyrolle[CodePlex]
The code coverage should be generated in LCOV format when runned by TFS. This would allow to inject the results into Sonar or any similar tool.

title: Generate tests results in junit xml format within TFS build
body:
ycrumeyrolle[CodePlex]
The tests results should generated in junit xml format when runned by TFS. This would allow to inject the results into Sonar or any similar tool. For now, it is only possible to generated those files with the console application.

title: Disabling code coverage in VS is not possible
body:
jyboudreau[CodePlex]
In our project we want to disable code coverage when running from visual studio with code coverage enabled. One of the reasons is the limited support for requirejs in the fact that when enabled it loads requirejs first in all cases. The EnableCodeCoverage option in Chutzpah.json file that was introduced recently seems like the ticket but it doesn't do anything when set to false. This can be seen from the code at TestContextBuilder.cs:376: if (!options.CoverageOptions.Enabled ampamp !chutzpahTestSettings.EnableCodeCoverage) return null; Suggestion: Change the EnableCodeCoverage to allow 3 values, quotfalse|true|autoquot. With auto being the current default (i.e. quotfalsequot) and quotfalsequot and quottruequot forcing the enabled state.

title: Detect code coverage setting in TFS Build
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
If a user configures their TFS build to run code coverage Chutzpah will see that and output its coverage .html file to the test run directory.

title: Add AMDBasePath property to Chutzpah.json
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Chutzpah needs to expose a AMDBasePath property in its chutzpah.json property to account for the case when a user specifies a baseurl require.js config option. Both paths should be kept in sync.

title: Support custom test name patterns
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Chutzpah figures out line numbers by using a regex to find the test name and match it to the result of running the test files. Chutzpah has hardcoded the most common patterns for mocha/jasmine/qunit. If you have a different pattern you should be able to set it using a regex string in the chutzpah.json file. This proposal is to add a key called TestPattern where you can specify the regex

title: TFS 2012 Build Server and ReferenceError: Can't find variable...
body:
johnny_reilly[CodePlex]
Hi, I've been experimenting with adding Chutzpah to our TFS 2012 build server. Initially everything looked promising but I encountered a ReferenceError issue as soon as I got beyond the initial use case. It sounds similar to https://chutzpah.codeplex.com/workitem/217 but whereas they're home and dry I am unfortunately not :-( The error I encountered was this: (names changed) ReferenceError: Can't find variable: xyz in file:///C:/Builds/1/ [...] /xyzTests.js (line 13) The xyz variable is defined in xyzViewModel.js and it is referenced in the test file like this: /// ltreference path=quot../../../../../Scripts/jasmine.jsquot chutzpah-exclude=quottruequot /gt /// ltreference path=quot../../../../../Scripts/Areas/Views/xyz/xyzViewModel.jsquot /gt xyzTests.js was given a BuildAction of None and a Copy to Output Directory of Copy always. xyzViewModel.js was given a BuildAction of Content and I changed the Copy to Output Directory to Copy always to try and rectify the problem. Unfortunately it didn't fix the issue. I'm a little stuck now and wondering if I'm missing something.... Any thoughts anyone? I'm using Chutzpah 3.1, I was following the instructions in the blog post on Javascript Unit Tests on Team Foundation Service with Chutzpah and the version of Chutzpah used on the build server was taken from the latest VSIX / zip. UPDATE I appear to have solved my problem. Step 7 of the blog post I was following says: Make sure that the js files (that contain the tests) are getting copied to the build output directory. This appears to suggest that test files should be set to quotCopy alwaysquot. Setting this to actually be quotDo not copyquot fixed my problem and I was able to confirm that tests were run as expected. So that's good news and I'm left with 2 small questions if anyone could pitch in: I'm presuming that Chutzpah must have changed since that blog post was written so the quotCopy alwaysquot step is no longer required. Is there any detail available on that? At present I have a quottestsquot folder in the root of my web app which duplicates the folder structure of the quotscriptsquot folder and contains any test files appropriately nested. The downside of this is that the tests get pushed out when I hit quotpublishquot which is not really what I want. Is there a straightforward way to prevent this?

title: Chutzpah, RequireJs and Mocking
body:
cpsjb[CodePlex]
Hi, We have upgraded to Chutzpah 3.1 and we are making great use of the support for Require which has greatly reduced the complexity of our tests when requiring async modules. The only issue we have now is that we want to use mocking for Require dependencies, so for example, a ViewModel might be under test, but this depends on a service module which goes off and gets data. We would like to mock the Service module when testing the ViewModel module. Before we upgraded Chutzpah, we were using the Squire framework but it does not look like this will be possible now, as Chutzpah takes care of requiring the module under test. Do you know if it possible to mock Require module dependencies in Chutzpah 3.1? We are using the Jasmine testing framework. Thanks for all of your time and help!

title: RequireJS BaseURL Problem
body:
cujo_r33[CodePlex]
When using Chutzpah with RequireJS, Chutzpah does not understand the baseurl in the requirejs config file, so when it generates the path to run tests, it doesn't use it. A workaround exists which is to not use the baseUrl, but instead just tell Chutzpah where to place the test harness. This is done by setting the TestHarnessDirectory property within the chutzpah.json file. A suggestion has been made to fix Chutzpah by allowing you to specify a relative AMD baseurl separately to Chutzpah in the chutzpah.json file. This would mean you would specify it in both the chutzpah.json and requirejs config files.

title: Files used as dependencies/references are instrumented by blanket even if they aren't the file being tested.
body:
edhedges[CodePlex]
Is there any way to include/exclude from code coverage on a per file basis. For example I have my directory structure like this: static\ scripts\ SomeModule\ GlobalObject.SomeModule.Utils.js GlobalObject.SomeModule.Models.js GlobalObject.SomeModule.js GlobalObject.js tests\ I replicate the directory and file structure in tests\, but on the files I insert .Tests right before the .js extension Okay so that being said. So if I wante to test GlobalObject.SomeModule.Models.js I would have a file named GlobalObject.SomeModule.Models.Tests.js. The way I have my tests and coverage set up I run each test file and only collect code coverage for the file that it's testing. To me it seems like code coverage on files not being tested is useless. So I let razor generate my html using a layout and all that and so I can include any .js files that are dependencies for the file I am wanting to test and add a data-cover flag to the script tag that I want covered. I'm just wondering is there a way to duplicate that functionality. For example it would be nice if you had to specify what you want covered instead of Chutzpah covering everything... Using the example above I would do this in my GlobalObject.SomeModule.Models.Tests.js file: /// ltchutzpah_reference path=quotGlobalObject.jsquot /gt /// ltchutzpah_reference path=quotGlobalObject.SomeModule.jsquot /gt /// ltchutzpah_reference path=quotGlobalObject.SomeModule.Models.jsquot data-cover /gt /\* Test code would go here and it would only be testing GlobalObject.SomeModule.Models.js thus that would be the only thing blanket needs to instrument/cover */ Please let me know your thoughts on this and I hope that it makes sense. I really like the idea of Chutzpah especially because of the Visual Studio and TFS integration, but currently it will not work for us, but that being said I don't think what I'm asking is too crazy seeing as that's how blanket.js works.

title: Specify which tests to run using Chutzpah.json file
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
To make test running simpler the chutzpah.json file should allow you to define which test files to run. Then to run tests you can just execute the chutzpah.json file itself. For example with a test settings file like: { quotTestsquot : [ {quotPathquot: quottest.jsquot } ] } You could run these tests by running: chutzpah.console.exe /path chutzpah.json

title: Embed .d.ts files for test frameworks
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
When using typescript the user is required to reference the correct .d.ts file. The problem is this must match the version which Chutzpah uses. Chutzpah should embed the correct .d.ts files automatically for Mocha, Qunit and Jasmine.

title: Decouple TypeScript engine from Chutzpah
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Chutzpah embeds TypeScript inside of the program but this makes it hard to support new releases and forces users to use the version that Chutzpah embeds. It would be better to make this more flexible and let users point to the version they want to use.

body:
wflores[CodePlex]
When using the quotOpen in browserquot menu extension on a TypeScript file, Chutzpah automatically generates javascript files that it uses to execute the unit tests. While these raw javascript files can be used in a browser's debugger, the original TypeScript sources cannot. This may because the generated javascript file does not have the comment that allows the browser to find an associated source map file (i.e. quot//# sourceMappingURL=typescriptsource.js.mapquot).

title: VS2012 Test Explorer does not detect tests

steve_b[CodePlex]
Hi, i've attached a small demo solution using Chutzpah 2.5.0 and require.js. The tests are loaded via require.js require(['mainConfig'], function () { var testModules = [ quotunittest.jsquot, ]; require(testModules); }); This works from browser, from Chutzpah context menu (Run JS Test on html and Open in browser). Problem is that the tests are not detected by the test explorer. Is there a workaround for that ? Thanks, Steve

title: Using Chutzpah to run Typescript qUnit tests - VS2012
body:
dougajmcdonald[CodePlex]
Hi there, I've recently tried to implement Chutzpah and qUnit to test some typescript code and have come up with an issue where I can run Chutzpah no problems to test a simple ok(quotyeyquot === quotyeyquot, quotoh no!quot) assertion in qUnit, but as soon as I try to dip into my TypeScript code I get: 'undefined' is not a constructor (evaluating 'new DMC.TreeBurst.Node({ id: 1, parentId: null, title: quotquot })') The DMC.TreeBurst.Node is a TypeScript class and my test is a simple demo: ///ltreference path=quot../typings/qunit/qunit.d.tsquot /gt ///ltreference path=quotreferences.tsquotgt ///ltreference path=quotreferences.jsquotgt module DMC.TreeBurst { ``` QUnit.module(quotTreeBurst.Node.ts testsquot); test(quotLoad-a-single-node-creates-correctlyquot, () =gt { var node = [new DMC.TreeBurst.Node({ id: 1, parentId: null, title: quotquot })]; ok(node, quotNode not create correctly with valid constructor parametersquot); }); ``` } I believe it may be some kind of namespacing/referencing issue as when I take the test out of my DMC.TreeBurst module it tells me it's unable to resolve DMC (the root namespace for my typescript application). Are there any tricks and tips on using Chutzpah with TypeScript and qUnit? I'd very much appreciate any suggestions or ideas. Kind Regards, Doug P.S. Also posted the same question on SO: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19986705/using-chutzpah-to-run-typescript-qunit-tests

In the trace-file, you can see it takes almost 3 seconds from sinon-1.7.3 is added, to the next log-message is displayed. title: shelling to chutzpah.console.exe from C# never returns
body:
thadeusd[CodePlex]
Hello! I'm trying to shell to the version 2.5.0 console exe and when kicking off the process from C# the process hangs and never returns. I have to loop and interrogate StdOut to know the task is complete. Using process.WaitForExit, or hooking the Process_Exited event both hang until I grow frustrated and kill them. Using the following code, the arguments variable is set to /debug /file chutzpah_test_runner.html chutzpah_test_runner.html is a copy of jasmine.html with the placeholders replaced by all of the test files. I'm attached a VS2012 repro demo. Had to remove Phantom.exe and the json.net nuget package to be under the 4 MB limit. You can either run the console app, or the unit test in the Build project. Uncomment this section to see the error (hopefully): // THIS DOES NOT WORK - NEVER RETURNS //process.WaitForExit(1000 \* 60 \* secondsToWait); Here is the relevant code... var process = new Process() { StartInfo = new ProcessStartInfo() { FileName = executable, Arguments = arguments, WorkingDirectory = workingDirectory, RedirectStandardError = true, RedirectStandardOutput = true, UseShellExecute = false } }; ``` process.Start(); var secondsToWait = 20; string IsComplete = quotTests completequot; string NoTests = quot0 total, 0 failedquot; string output = string.Empty; // THIS DOES NOT WORK - NEVER RETURNS //process.WaitForExit(1000 * 60 * secondsToWait); // THIS DOES WORK // wait for 20 seconds total // check each second to see if the process has exited for (var i = 0; i lt secondsToWait; i++) { output = process.StandardOutput.ReadToEnd(); if (output.Contains(IsComplete) || output.Contains(NoTests)) { break; } else { Debug.WriteLine(quotWaiting {0} of {1} seconds for results...quot, i + 1, secondsToWait); process.Refresh(); Thread.Sleep(1000); } } string error = process.StandardError.ReadToEnd(); process.Close(); return string.IsNullOrEmpty(error) ampamp !output.Contains(NoTests) ampamp TestsPassed(output); ``` Any thoughts?? PS: This works just perfectly when I run this from the command line. It only doesn't work when I run this from within C#... Thanks! Thad

title: Placement of compiled TypeScript files, issues with Bundling
body:
JPS78[CodePlex]
Running Chutzpah with TypeScript the compiled .js files are placed in the same folder as the .ts file. This causes issues with bundling since a bundle could include all .js in a folder which (after running test with Chutzpah) includes the .js files that chutzpah has compiled. Bundling a complete folder is very common if you have a large amount of .ts files. Is it possible to : have a testfolder that contains all reccessary files for the test: .html in the root the root is the common folder base for all testfiles. configure the testfolder path, Example: Test structure: C:\Projects\Solution1\TestProject\BrowserTest.ts C:\Projects\Solution1\WebApplicaition1\Scripts\BrowserTest.ts TestFolder path: C:\Projects\Solution1\TestProject\TestsCache This would give the testfolder: Root: C:\Projects\Solution1\TestProject\TestsCache\c108fc155bec3def8d323ea7928455c0 Contents: C:\Projects\Solution1\TestProject\TestsCache\c108fc155bec3def8d323ea7928455c0\TestProject\BrowserTest.js C:\Projects\Solution1\TestProject\TestsCache\c108fc155bec3def8d323ea7928455c0\WebApplicaition1\Scripts\BrowserTest.js C:\Projects\Solution1\TestProject\TestsCache\c108fc155bec3def8d323ea7928455c0_Chutzpah.test.html Pros: All files for a testrun within a folder No conflict with bundling when running the site, since the .js files that chutzpah compiles is placed in a text folder outside the webapplication.

NTaylorMullen[CodePlex]
In a project that I'm working on we currently have around 300 very verbose tests. Chutzpah is integrated into the build system so we run the following command at build time: chutzpah.console.exe myTestSuite.html /silent /debug /timeoutMilliseconds 30000 Now the output of the tests is very verbose so the console is then flooded with log messages (a good thing). On occasion there'll be failing tests and the console will contain something like quotx number of tests failedquot etc. at the very end of the exe run. This is great in determining that tests failed but not so great in determining which tests and why they failed. In essence I could scroll up and look through the several thousand lines of debug output in an attempt to find out what tests failed and why but with so many lines of output it becomes pretty impossible. It'd be great if the debug option also re-output the failing tests and their corresponding logs at the end of the test run. This way all failures are in one location and are easy to decipher potential failure causes.

title: Support for HTML template imports
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
We use external template files all the time for things like jQuery widgets etc. and needed to add support to include these so that we could test rendering. The code it fairly simple but in a nutshell you include a quotnewquot xml comment type: /// lttemplate path=quotsome.tmpl.htmlquot/gt The contents of that file look like: ltscript id=quottemplateIdquot type=quottext/htmlquotgt...lt/scriptgt Chutspah will then read the contents of some.tmpl.html file and insert into the head before any of the JS Files. this will give you something that looks like: lt!DOCTYPE htmlgtlthtmlgtltheadgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotfile:///TestFiles/qunit.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltlink rel=quotstylesheetquot type=quottext/cssquot href=quotfile:///TestFiles/qunit.cssquot/gt ltscript id=quottemplateIdquot type=quottext/htmlquotgt...lt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotfile:///path/references.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotfile:///path/test.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt lt/headgt ltbodygtltdiv id=quotqunit-fixturequotgtlt/divgtlt/bodygtlt/htmlgt

title: Simplify test running
body:
WickyNilliams[CodePlex]
Hey I'm just playing about with Chutzpah and so far it's worked great running my spec.html file. However maintaining the spec.html file is an overhead I'd rather not have. I considered adding /// reference declarations to my test files, but I then hit a snag whereby I have to specify each file individually to test when calling chutzpah. Can I propose a few ideas to ease test runs: The first solution would be to allow globbing of files names, much like you do with code coverage, so i can give a pattern for all my tests. That way the spec files themselves are the one truth (no spec.html!), and I won't have to write a powershell script to do this for me. the second option is inspired the grunt-jasmine task (if you're unfamiliar with grunt, it's a JS based task runner for builds, tests etc). Basically, to configure the grunt-jasmine task you can use a configuration like this: jasmine : { options : { specs : 'spec/_.js' }, src : 'src/_.js' }, As you can see, this allows me to glob both my source and spec files, meaning I never have to update my configuration after the initial setup and I don't have to worry about maintaining a spec.html or /// reference declarations. For more info, see then grunt-jasmine readme Let me know what you thinkI

title: Customizable HTML Harnesses
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Chutzpah is a more effective test runner when you can run directly on your js/coffee/ts files however for some scenarios (like with AMD) you want more control and need to author your own test harness file. To bridge this gap Chutzpah should provide a test harness template feature. Using this you will be able to specify in your chutzpah.json a path to a test harness template. In this template you will be able to tell Chutzpah where to put the test files, js files etc. For example this is currently what Chutzpah uses internally for a qunit HTML test harness template: lt!DOCTYPE htmlgt lthtmlgt ltheadgt @@TestFrameworkDependencies@@ @@ReferencedCSSFiles@@ @@ReferencedJSFiles@@ @@TestJSFile@@ lt/headgt ltbodygt lth1 id=quotqunit-headerquotgtUnit Testslt/h1gt lth2 id=quotqunit-bannerquotgtlt/h2gt lth2 id=quotqunit-userAgentquotgtlt/h2gt ltol id=quotqunit-testsquotgtlt/olgt ltdiv id=quotqunit-fixturequotgtlt/divgt lt/bodygt lt/htmlgt The words with @@ around them are placeholders that Chutzpah fills in for you. I think this method will allow people to have full customizablity and still get the benefits of running on JS files.

title: Code Coverage errors if any uri is a mapped drive path
body:
MattRetallack[CodePlex]
If you run code coverage against a file on a local or mapped drive, then BlanketJsCoverageEngine fails to convert the URI into a valid file path. An example stack trace: Chutzpah Error: System.AggregateException: One or more errors occurred. System.NotSupportedException: The given path's format is not supported. at System.IO.FileStream.Init(String path, FileMode mode, FileAccess access, Int32 rights, Boolean useRights, FileShare share, Int32 bufferSize, FileOptions options, SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES secAttrs, String msgPath, Boolean bFromProxy, Boolean useLongPath, Boolean checkHost) at System.IO.FileStream..ctor(String path, FileMode mode, FileAccess access, FileShare share, Int32 bufferSize, FileOptions options, String msgPath, Boolean bFromProxy, Boolean useLongPath, Boolean checkHost) at System.IO.StreamReader..ctor(String path, Encoding encoding, Boolean detectEncodingFromByteOrderMarks, Int32 bufferSize, Boolean checkHost) at System.IO.StreamReader..ctor(String path, Encoding encoding) at System.IO.File.InternalReadAllLines(String path, Encoding encoding) at System.IO.File.ReadAllLines(String path) at Chutzpah.Wrappers.FileSystemWrapper.GetLines(String path) at Chutzpah.Coverage.BlanketJsCoverageEngine.DeserializeCoverageObject(String json, TestContext testContext) at Chutzpah.TestCaseStreamReader.ReadFromStream(StreamReader stream, TestContext testContext, ITestMethodRunnerCallback callback, Boolean debugEnabled) at Chutzpah.TestCaseStreamReader.ltgtc__DisplayClass1.ltReadgtb__0() at System.Threading.Tasks.Task`1.InnerInvoke() at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.Execute() --- End of inner exception stack trace --- at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.ThrowIfExceptional(Boolean includeTaskCanceledExceptions) at System.Threading.Tasks.Task`1.GetResultCore(Boolean waitCompletionNotification) at System.Threading.Tasks.Task`1.get_Result() at Chutzpah.TestCaseStreamReader.Read(ProcessStream processStream, TestOptions testOptions, TestContext testContext, ITestMethodRunnerCallback callback, Boolean debugEnabled) at Chutzpah.TestRunner.ltgtc__DisplayClass5.ltInvokeTestRunnergtb__4(ProcessStream processStream) at Chutzpah.ProcessHelper.RunExecutableAndProcessOutputT at Chutzpah.TestRunner.InvokeTestRunner(String headlessBrowserPath, TestOptions options, TestContext testContext, TestRunnerMode testRunnerMode, ITestMethodRunnerCallback callback) at Chutzpah.TestRunner.ltgtc__DisplayClass2.ltProcessTestPathsgtb__1(PathInfo testFile) ---gt (Inner Exception #0) System.NotSupportedException: The given path's format is not supported. at System.IO.FileStream.Init(String path, FileMode mode, FileAccess access, Int32 rights, Boolean useRights, FileShare share, Int32 bufferSize, FileOptions options, SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES secAttrs, String msgPath, Boolean bFromProxy, Boolean useLongPath, Boolean checkHost) at System.IO.FileStream..ctor(String path, FileMode mode, FileAccess access, FileShare share, Int32 bufferSize, FileOptions options, String msgPath, Boolean bFromProxy, Boolean useLongPath, Boolean checkHost) at System.IO.StreamReader..ctor(String path, Encoding encoding, Boolean detectEncodingFromByteOrderMarks, Int32 bufferSize, Boolean checkHost) at System.IO.StreamReader..ctor(String path, Encoding encoding) at System.IO.File.InternalReadAllLines(String path, Encoding encoding) at System.IO.File.ReadAllLines(String path) at Chutzpah.Wrappers.FileSystemWrapper.GetLines(String path) at Chutzpah.Coverage.BlanketJsCoverageEngine.DeserializeCoverageObject(String json, TestContext testContext) at Chutzpah.TestCaseStreamReader.ReadFromStream(StreamReader stream, TestContext testContext, ITestMethodRunnerCallback callback, Boolean debugEnabled) at Chutzpah.TestCaseStreamReader.ltgtc__DisplayClass1.ltReadgtb__0() at System.Threading.Tasks.Task`1.InnerInvoke() at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.Execute() The bug is due to a limitation of Uri.LocalPath, which does not convert local drive-letter based file paths correctly. If the URI represents a path of the form: file:///c:/myfile.js Then uri.LocalPath will return: /c:/myfile.js It should return: c:/myfile.js instead. A work-around is to apply the following after getting uri.LocalPath (around line 115 of BlanketJsCoverageEngine.cs): string filePath = uri.LocalPath; // fix local paths of the form: file:///c:/zzz should become c:/zzz not /c:/zzz // but keep network paths of the form: file://network/files/zzz as //network/files/zzz filePath = new Regex(@quot^\/([a-zA-Z]:/)quot).Replace(filePath, quot$1quot); Local drive URIs are incorrect without the three forward-slash characters between file: and the drive letter, but UNC drive-letter paths are invalid with a prefixed forward-slash. See: http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2006/12/06/file-uris-in-windows.aspx

title: QUnit test runner module gotcha in 2.3
body:
andrewgee[CodePlex]
Hi there, I just came across a little gotcha with the QUnit test runner in 2.3. In qunitRunner.js, the following code: function onQUnitLoaded() { ``` // If additional referenced to QUnit are loaded trick them to not pollute global namespace window.exports = window.exports || {}; ``` causes some libraries, e.g., PubSub, lodash, to think they're in a CommonJS environment and therefore not register themselves in the global namespace. I came across it when some of my tests started breaking in the console but not when running in the browser. I got around it by adding an extra script include at the head of the references list that removed windows.export and all worked fine after that. This is really a QUnit problem, more details at: https://github.com/jquery/qunit/issues/190 Cheers, Andrew

title: Method 'ToXml' in type 'Chutzpah.VS2012.TestAdapter.ChutzpahAdapterSettings' does not have an implementation
body:
greggbjensen[CodePlex]
Error: Method 'ToXml' in type 'Chutzpah.VS2012.TestAdapter.ChutzpahAdapterSettings' from assembly 'Chutzpah.VS2012.TestAdapter, Version=2.1.0.162, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=1ca802c37ffe1896' does not have an implementation. We are using TFS 2012 and VS 2012 with .NET 4.5. The problem is at VS2012.TestAdapter\ChutzpahAdapterSettings.cs in the ToXml method. It could be the override does not match that of the loaded assembly of Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.ObjectModel.dll. from LoRez: quot...It looks like I have a newer version of the Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.ObjectModel.dll on my machine. My machine has version 11.0.51106.1 in C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 11.0\Common7\IDE\CommonExtensions\Microsoft\TestWindow. Whereas the adapter seems to be using version 11.0.50907.0. It looks like the signature for ToXml hasn't changed from what you've implemented...quot This problem does not seem to occur with tfs.visualstudio.com, but on a stand-alone build server. I believe the reason that this problem cannot be reproduced on tfs.visualstudio.com is that it only happens when Visual Studio 2012 is installed on the build server. That way it cannot load the version of Microsoft.VisualStudio.TestPlatform.ObjectModel.dll from your build assemblies folder because it is already loaded in memory on the build server.

title: jasmin-jQuery toContain tests fail with reason "Passed."
body:
oilytheotter[CodePlex]
I've got some tests that use jasmin-jQuery's toContain(jQuerySelector) matcher to check for the existence of an input tag in some html that was loaded by jasmine-jQuery's loadFixtures(fixtureUrl[, fixtureUrl, ...]) All my tests pass in Chrome, but tests that use the toContain matcher fail in Chutzpah 2.3.0 with the following message: Test 'Keyboard:should have 13 buttons when the accept button option is set' failed Passed. in C:\bschoenfeld\OPs_Service_Bus\VIT.NIT.OPS.HatchChecker\WebServer\Apps\HatchChecker\test\SpecRunner.html (line 0) Here is the failing test: it(quotshould have 13 buttons when the accept button option is setquot, function() { var keyboard = new Keyboard.View({ placeholder: '', acceptButton: true }); keyboard.render(); expect(keyboard.$el).toContain('input'); expect(keyboard.$('.btn').length).toBe(13); }); The work around is to explicitly call the jQuery selector in the test and check the length. This test passes in Chutzpah: it(quotshould have 13 buttons when the accept button option is setquot, function() { var keyboard = new Keyboard.View({ placeholder: '', acceptButton: true }); keyboard.render(); expect(keyboard.$('input').length).toBe(1); expect(keyboard.$('.btn').length).toBe(13); }); The toContain matcher works in Chutzpah if it's inverted with the .not prefix. This test also passes in Chutzpah: it(quotshould have 12 buttonsquot, function() { var keyboard = new Keyboard.View; keyboard.render(); expect(keyboard.$el).not.toContain('input'); expect(keyboard.$('.btn').length).toBe(12); });

title: No tests found when using QUnit.test instead of test

gusgus84[CodePlex]
QUinit exposes namespaced and global variations, but Chutzpah will only run the test if you use the global variation. Works: test(quotMy Testquot, function () { ... }); Doesn't work: QUinit.test(quotMy Testquot, function () { ... });

title: Allow including files without building them
body:
gusgus84[CodePlex]
I want to be able to reference a JavaScript file from my TypeScript test, but it's not TypeScript compliant, so I want it as part of the output, but not part of the build. This is similar to http://chutzpah.codeplex.com/workitem/92 but the reverse condition.

title: Allow references to be excluded
body:
Qube[CodePlex]
Sometimes you only want to use ltreference /gt annotations for intellisense (their original purpose), not for testing. For example if you were to write a JavaScript module using an external library, you'll likely add a reference to it for the helpful autocomplete at design time. But if you decide to use a fake version of the library for unit testing (referenced in the test suite), the two will end up colliding when Chutzpah spiders through the references - the fake version from the suite, and the real version from the class under test. Add the ability to exclude a reference.

title: Improve "/openInBrowser"
body:
p4fg[CodePlex]
When using /openInBrowser, Chutzpah always first run all test-cases before opening the browser. In my opinion this is not neccessary, because: I requested the tests to be run in the browser, probably because I need to debug something If i have an error somewhere in my code, leading to loops and tests that does not finish in time, chutzpah terminates without opening in the browser. This makes it very hard to debug where the loop is. Suggestion: When using the /openInBrowser flag, prepare all files as usual, but do not run the tests in chutzpah, open the browser immediately and then exit without displaying any statistics (there are none). Cheers! /p4fg

title: No tests found when using require.js, jquery, and underscore
body:
cammerman[CodePlex]
I have a situation where Chutzpah is completing with no tests executed, even though there are tests present. There is no error message, it just says zero tests found. I have distilled the situation down to the barest elements necessary for reproduction. I am using require.js for module management, and have tests in a module which requires both jquery and underscore, which are used for convenience in the real tests. I use a shim for underscore, since it is not an AMD module. When both dependencies are present in the test module definition, Chutzpah finds no tests. If I comment out either one of the two dependencies, it does find the tests in the module. I have reference directives in the test module as well, but their presence or absence seems to have no effect. The file structure of the project is completely flat at present, for simplicity's sake, but putting the 3rd party libraries in a sub-folder and adding path directives has had no effect either. Attached are the test harness, the test module, and a screenshot showing the file structure.

title: Excluding Visual Studio Intellisense Files (vsdoc files) from additional reference paths
body:
FranWahl[CodePlex]
Hi We are running Chutzpah 2.2.1 in Visual Studio 2010 had some issues with vsdoc files which are unexpectantly loaded during tests. We have the following references in our test file: /// ltreference path=quotjquery-1.7.1-vsdoc.jsquot /gt /// ltreference path=quotjquery-1.7.1.jsquot /gt /// ltreference path=quotFileUnderTest.jsquot /gt The file-under-test quotFileUnderTest.jsquot has the following reference paths for intellisense purpose: /// ltreference path=quotjquery-1.7.1-vsdoc.jsquot /gt /// ltreference path=quotNotifications.jsquot /gt The file quotNotifications.jsquot is another one of our files which has the following reference paths: /// ltreference path=quotjquery-1.5.1-vsdoc.jsquot /gt /// ltreference path=quotjquery.validate-vsdoc.jsquot /gt This results in the following scripts to be included in the Head when running the tests in the browser: ltheadgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotfile:///C:/xxx/jquery-1.7.1.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotfile:///C:/xxx/jquery-1.5.1-vsdoc.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotfile:///C:/xxx/jquery.validate-vsdoc.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotfile:///C:/xxx/Notifications.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotfile:///C:/xxx/FileUnderTest.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt lt/headgt As you can see above, quotjquery-1.5.1-vsdoc.jsquot and quotjquery.validate-vsdoc.jsquot are both loaded as well. It seems that any vsdoc files referenced by either the test file or the file-under-test file such as the quotquotjquery-1.7.1-vsdoc.jsquot above, are ignored as I would have expected. However, it seems that any files referenced by the file-under-test file, such as the quotNotifications.jsquot above, has all their referenced vsdoc files loaded. That caused an issue for us as the jquery-1.5.1-vsdoc.js file contains the line quotvar jQuery = (function() {...}quot overwriting the 1.7.1 jquery object during testing. In our particular example above we had legacy vsdoc references in our files to 1.5.1, left from a previous jquery upgrade but I would have expected those files to be ignored by Chutzpah. When we updated the vsdoc reference in quotNotifications.jsquot to the correct 1.7.1 vsdoc version, Chutzpah crashed as it overwrote the 1.7.1 jquery object with the 1.7.1 vsdoc jquery object, preventing Chutzpah to load the tests in the browser all together. I would have expected for no vsdoc files to be loaded. Could you let me know please if this is expected behaviour or if indeed those vsdoc files should not be loaded.

title: Reference root path should be project
body:
johano[CodePlex]
If you add a ltreference path=quot/quot /gt to include all files in root folder, it appears like c: is scanned recursively? The current visual studio project could be the root here, so the only needed reference is the line ltreference path=quot/_references.jsquot /gt in all test files Another useful feature could be configurable constants, for the case where you have your tests in one VS project, and the target in another. Something like ltreference path=quot$TargetProject/viewmodels/myViewModel.jsquot /gt A settings file could contain these settings and be included in the solution to share the settings in the team.

title: Compile all TypeScript files at the same time
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
There is a major issue with how Chutzpah is compiling the TypeScript files. TypeScript's compiling does not work correctly on files that reference types in other files unless they are all referenced together. To fix this Chutzpah needs to change how it calls the TypeScript compiler. Currently, Chutzpah compiles each file one by one but instead it needs to pass them all in as a batch to the TypeScript compiler

title: Running with parallelism gives faulty timing
body:
p4fg[CodePlex]
Running with /parallelism will aggregate the total time for all threads and will not display the actual running time for running the tests in parallel.

title: System.UnauthorizedAccessException when running chutzpah.console.exe from TFS
body:
gurumusch[CodePlex]
Hi Matthew, I have locally fixed this issue but I want to share the knowledge ... We run chutzpah in a post-build event and the problematic build was triggered as a gated-checkin build from the TFS Service. The output was: Chutzpah console test runner (64-bit .NET 4.0.30319.269) Copyright (C) 2012 Matthew Manela (http://matthewmanela.com). chutzpah.dll: Version 2.1.0.162 Chutzpah Error: System.UnauthorizedAccessException: Access to the path 'C:\Users\TFSBUILD\AppData\Local\Temp\7f5116856bdb6c811732a9ad277f5fec\jasmine.js' is denied. at System.IO.__Error.WinIOError(Int32 errorCode, String maybeFullPath) at System.IO.File.InternalCopy(String sourceFileName, String destFileName, Boolean overwrite) at Chutzpah.TestContextBuilder.CreateIfDoesNotExist(String sourcePath, String destinationPath) in c:\Dev\chutzpah\Chutzpah\TestContextBuilder.cs:line 215 at Chutzpah.TestContextBuilder.BuildContext(String file) in c:\Dev\chutzpah\Chutzpah\TestContextBuilder.cs:line 101 at Chutzpah.TestContextBuilder.TryBuildContext(String file, TestContextamp context) in c:\Dev\chutzpah\Chutzpah\TestContextBuilder.cs:line 125 at Chutzpah.TestRunner.ltgtc__DisplayClass2.ltProcessTestPathsgtb__1(String testFile) in c:\Dev\chutzpah\Chutzpah\TestRunner.cs:line 141 While Running:C:\Builds\7\27\Sources\Code\Base\Main\Solution\Project\path\to\Test.test.js === 0 total, 0 failed, took 0,00 seconds === For consistency purpose we have Chutzpah checked in the TFS - so I have the same file versions. But when I login on the TFS system and start the build per msbuild I don't get the error. The error occures because: The jasmine files in the chutzpah folder are read-only (because they came from TFS) The TFS-Service is running 24/7 and therefore gets the same temporary folder for the tests So chutzpah copies the jasmine files (including the readonly flag) to the temp-folder and the first build passes without errors but every further build has this error because it tries to overwrite a readonly file ... So as mentioned above I have corrected the readonly flags on the files manually. But it took some time to realized the problem ... Greetz, Andreas

title: Issue with temp Javascript file created from TypeScript during test run
body:
vrossi[CodePlex]
The output of the temp javascript file is inconsistent from the javascript file that is output when I save a TypeScript file in Visual Studio. Also, it appears like it's missing the necessary code to make quot_superquot work properly and is causing my tests to fail. Here's an example... Here is the output when I save the TypeScript file in Visual Studio: var Test = (function (_super) { __extends(Test, _super); function Test() { _super.call(this); } This is the output of the temp file that is created when running tests: var Test = (function () { function Test() { _super.prototype(); } You'll notice that the initial function definition is missing the _super parameter as well as the call to __extends. When this object is created it tries to call _super.prototype() and fails. I'm not sure is there is a different with the settings you're using when compiling the TypeScript into Javascript, but if I just use the output Javascript from TypeScript file, everything works great.

title: Allow <reference> paths for folders
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
In a script file you should be able to write ltreference path=quotsome/folder/pathquot /gt This will recursively reference all files in that folder. This can be helpful to manage having many references.

mmanela[CodePlex]
Add support for TypeScript

title: Relative path script reference intermittently not found
body:
apocko[CodePlex]
I have a unit test project containing a Jasmine unit test script. This references the target with a relative path, like this: /// ltreference path=quotjasmine.jsquot /gt /// ltreference path=quotjquery.jsquot /gt /// ltreference path=quot../TargetProject/Content/Scripts/target.jsquot /gt In other words, I have this structure: --TargetProject ----Content ------Scripts --------target.js --TestProject ----tests.js When VS loads, this path is resolved just fine, and all of the tests are found and placed in Test Explorer. For a while things work OK. But every now and then, after tests.js is updated, the unit tests disappear from Test Explorer. When this happens, the JavaScript Language Service output window contains this message: Referenced file '../TargetProject/Content/Scripts/target.js' not found. I then have to restart Visual Studio to restore those unit tests (though sometimes the tests do return). References to the other scripts in the same folder seem to work fine since there is no error message for them. I'm using VS 2012 and Chutzpah 2.1.0 (the test runner and test adapter).

title: Make it easier to implement custom test runners
body:
gatapia[CodePlex]
Currently BaseFrameworkDefinition.cs hardcodes the supported test runners. Would be much better if test runners themselves determined if they support a JS file. So simply load all the runners in the JSRunners directory and add a simple function: function isSupportedTestFile(fileName, contents); So my customRunner.js would simply implement this function and you then continue on as per usual. This would allow others just to add custom runners without even requiring the source to Chutzpah. I guess this would add a slight overhead but I cannot imagine it would be a considerable amount.

title: Add support for writing tests in coffee script
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Chutzpah should be able to run tests that are written in coffeescript

title: Add option to ouput test results to XML file
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Test runners like Hudson, Jenkins and Cruise Control can read a JUnit style XML file. This will let Chutzpah better integrate into these CI tools. This SO post http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4922867/junit-xml-format-specification-that-hudson-supports shows the require format.

title: Generated test harness does not run in FireFox 12+
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
I tested in FireFox 12+ and the generated test harness does not work correctly. It looks like it fails to load the test path which is a windows path (e.g. C:\somepath\file.js). This same test harness works in IE and Chrome.

title: Fix test output for QUnit ok assert
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
When a QUnit test has an quotokquot assert that fails the console runner ouputs: Galleries.url.postAsyncWithCallback:Will execute callback [FAIL] Test '[testname]' failed Expected: undefined, Actual: undefined This is less than ideal. Instead if should just says Assert Failed

title: Prevent Phantom from deadlocking
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
There are certain situations where Phantom will hang and never die. Chutzpah should detect this and kill the process

title: Stream test results as they finish
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Instead of waiting for a test file to finish before reporting the results Chutzpah should report when each test starts and finishes

title: Add better support for RequireJS
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Add better support for RequireJS for both HTML files and JS files

title: Change chutzpah.console.exe output to support VS error list integration
body:
WizzApp[CodePlex]
Please change the output of the console to support integration in VS (see http://blogs.msdn.com/b/msbuild/archive/2006/11/03/msbuild-visual-studio-aware-error-messages-and-message-formats.aspx). This allows chutzpah.console.exe to be used in a MSBuild Exec Task (for example to be executed on every build). Alternatively you could also add an MSBuild task or an option for the extension to be run on every build.

title: Console Runner hangs on html file
body:
CraigMaslowski[CodePlex]
The attached simple html file runs fine in browser, but when run with the console runner, it just hangs. I'm not sure why it's failing, but I did find that there should be an else condition in pageOpenHandler when checking status to exit phantom if page.open fails.

title: Preserve Dependency Order for referenced files
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
If a test references A.js. And A.js references file B.js. Then the test harness file that Chutzpah is generating places the script references in the order: A.js, B.js, followed by the test. This seems wrong, and it causes some of our scripts to throw exceptions. The expected order in the test harness should be: B, A, test.

title: Expose PhantomJS options
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
PhantomJS has several settings that can be useful for a user to toggle such as: javascriptEnabled defines whether to execute the script in the page or not (default to true) loadImages defines whether to load the inlined images or not localToRemoteUrlAccessEnabled defines whether local resource (e.g. from file) can access remote URLs or not (default to false) userAgent defines the user agent sent to server when the web page requests resources. userName sets the user name used for HTTP authentication password sets the password used for HTTP authentication XSSAuditingEnabled defines whether load requests should be monitored for cross-site scripting attempts (default to false) webSecurityEnabled defines whether web security should be enabled or not (default to `true) These should be exposed from both the command line and the VS options page.

title: Add better logging
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Implement trace information throughout chutzpah to help enable better debugging.

title: Test discovery reports incorrect suite name for nested jasmine suites
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
When you perform test discovery on a jasmine file that has nested suites only the name of the deepest nested suite gets reported. However, if you perform test execution on the same test file it reports the suite name as the full name (included all parent suites). Update the test discovery to be consistent with the test execution naming.

title: Fix referenced file expansion
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Chutzpah 1.4.0 added supported for having referenced files in your tests that contain a references to other dependencies. However, Chutzpah is incorrectly trying to resolve these paths relative to the original test file rather than from the current referenced file.

title: expected and actual result are not shown in Visual Studio
body:
ewaldhofman[CodePlex]
When you run the tests with the chutzpah.console.exe it shows the expected and actual results on failing tests, but not in Visual Studio

title: Unexpected character encountered while parsing value: U. Line 1, position 1
body:
NickJosevski[CodePlex]
When a file has a reference path link at the top, Chutzpah test runner falls over. /// ltreference path=quot../../../f1/f2/file.jsquot /gt Full error up on: http://pastebin.com/239vKC58

title: Prevent temporary folder explosion
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Chutzpah creates a new temporary folder each time you run a test. This can add up quick and your temp folder can becomes quite large. Instead of using a random folder name take a hash of the test file path. This will solve the issue as well as make the StagingFolder Test Option unnecessary so this will be removed.

title: Run in browser results in blank page for Jasmine Tests
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
A bug was introduced that causes quotrun test in browserquot to not work for jasmine.

title: Support for retrieving JS dependencies through references.js
body:
bpasero[CodePlex]
Hi, would it be possible to allow to receive the list of dependencies of a test through 1 references.js file? In a larger project this would allow to keep dependencies in one place instead of having to update them across all tests. It would work like this: from a test require a references.js file (/// ltreference path=quot../references.jsquot /gt) inside the references.js one would list all the dependencies using /// ltreference... as before Thanks

title: Add support for Jasmine reporters to write to a file
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
The Jasmine-Reporters project ( https://github.com/larrymyers/jasmine-reporters) adds support to a Phantom Jasmine test runner which can write an xml report to a file. Their runner (https://github.com/larrymyers/jasmine-reporters/blob/master/test/phantomjs-testrunner.js) accomplishes this by stashing the result in the window variable and then grabs it from the hosting page and writes it to disk once execution is finished. To support this scenario we need to add similar logic to the jasmineRunner.js file in Chutzpah.

title: Improve line number detection
body:
mmanela[CodePlex]
Chutzpah uses a simple heuristic to try to match test's to line numbers. For example, given a qunit test file it will scan the filing recording the line number of each instance of quottest(quot and then after tests are run match the test run to the index of each quottest(quot call. This is a very fragile implementation that fails in a couple scenarios. If you are using a framework that adds its own verbage for tests (like Pavalov.js) this matching completely fails. If you wrap your test in a loop, Chutzpah will fail to give correct line numbers. I have not thought about a more robust implementation yet, thoughts are welcome.

title: Command Line Runner to support Jasmine tests

Enable the command line runner to work with jasmine unit tests

title: Use custom reporter instead of parsing HTML
body:
Dan15[CodePlex]
jasmineRunner.js parses the HTML output from Jasmine in order to determine which tests have passed and which tests have failed. This works, but would be reliant on HTML output in a specific format. Jasmine supports the notion of quotreportersquot, which are basically classes that take the Jasmine data and output it in a usable format. See jasmine-html.js for an example of a report (the default reporter that comes with Jasmine). Instead of parsing HTML, a custom reporter could be used to directly exposes the required data (perhaps as a JSON object). This would be more reliable than parsing HTML.

title: Support Jasmine-species (doesn't use it())
body:
Dan15[CodePlex]
Chutzpah's Jasmine support seems pretty good, but it appears to detect Jasmine tests by searching for quotit(...)quot anywhere in the file (RegexPatterns.cs and JasmineDefinition.cs). Jasmine-species1 is an addin to Jasmine that adds additional test styles. Notably, it adds the ability to use BDD scenario (quotgiven, when, thenquot) syntax2. Chutzpah doesn't detect these test files as Jasmine tests, and hence doesn't run them correctly. I managed to get it working by adding the correct references (via /// ltreference ...gt) and adding a comment like the following: /// it('dummy') However, this does seem like a hack. A short-term fix might be to search for quotgiven(...)quot and quotfeature(...)quot as well as quotit(...)quot.

title: Detect and exclude qunit references
body:
Qube[CodePlex]
If a script includes a reference to qunit.js for the sake of intellisense, do not include it in the test run. Having the script included twice (see below) causes some strange issues, and could throw off the validity of the tests (like if the version of qunit differs between Chutzpah and the reference). For example: /// ltreference path=quot../scripts/lib/jquery-1.6.4-vsdoc.jsquot /gt /// ltreference path=quot../scripts/lib/qunit.jsquot /gt /// ltreference path=quot../scripts/my.library.jsquot /gt Should not result in: ltheadgt ltlink rel=quotstylesheetquot href=quotqunit.cssquot type=quottext/cssquot/gt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotqunit.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotmolu5nlu.diz_jquery-1.6.4-vsdoc.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotwdmjm0hm.irn_qunit.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotla5xktlh.3rx_my.library.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotmy.library-test.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt lt/headgt But should have the second qunit excluded like this: ltheadgt ltlink rel=quotstylesheetquot href=quotqunit.cssquot type=quottext/cssquot/gt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotqunit.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotmolu5nlu.diz_jquery-1.6.4-vsdoc.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotla5xktlh.3rx_my.library.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt ltscript type=quottext/javascriptquot src=quotmy.library-test.jsquotgtlt/scriptgt lt/headgt

title: Full-support for Windows Forms application
body:
Add `DiffViewer` control (in `DiffPlex.WindowsForms.Controls` namespace) for Windows Forms application. The control is still in `DiffPlex.Wpf.dll` assembly because it is rendered by the WPF control via `ElementHost` in the internal implementation but wrap as a Windows Forms control, so that means,

- It exports the interface as the familiar way to use in Windows Forms;
- It looks like WPF but in fact not; and,
- It will not impact the existing projects that reference to WPF controls.

![Demo in Windows Forms application](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1724940/111059129-065fc080-84ce-11eb-8475-f17d16bae314.jpg)

And the new project `DiffPlex.WindowsForms.Demo` is to demo how to use (#51). So the old demo (#66) is removed from the solution.

title: Refactor the feature to collapse unchanged sections
body:
#67 **Ignore unchanged lines** is a notable feature to enable a way to collapse some of lines unchanged. I appreciate the contributor/author to provide such great idea and cost time to implement it.

In this PR, I have rewritten those codes by a different new way to boost performance and to apply it to all controls.

### Performance enhancement

Speed up to 3-6x (test locally) in following scenarios.

- Toggle between the mode of if need to collapse unchanged sections.
- Modify the count of the context line. Context lines are the ones unchanged around others but keep visible to let end-users have a way to get context.

### Controls

The old implementation was only for `DiffViewer` control but now (in this PR) this feature also supports `SideBySideDiffViewer` control and `InlineDiffViewer` control.

Plus, for context menu of header in `DiffViewer` control, I have also added the menu items to get and set the count of the context line directly when the unchanged sections are collapsed.

![Screenshot_20210312_DiffPlex_FoldLines](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1724940/110924756-62ef9e00-835d-11eb-9bca-42a364fb8e1a.jpg)

### Other updates

Fix following bugs brought in by old implementation to ignore unchanged lines. It re-organizes the input data but neglects some corner-cases. These codes have been removed/reverted here during I rewrite all the logic.

- In particular cases, the last line of old text may miss if that line is not empty but the new one is.
- Fails to run if the old text is empty. Sounds #70 also want to fix this issue but no need now.

And improve following items.

- Robustness optimization to avoid the exception thrown mentioned in #55.
- Optimize for identical texts.

title: Add context menu for WPF controls
body:
### Line context menu

Allow you copy a specific line from context menu.

1. Right click the text.
2. Click *Copy this line* in the context menu.

![Context menu of a line](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1724940/110648641-d9708c80-81f3-11eb-8c31-5422b6efd18a.png)

Applied to following controls.

- `DiffPlex.Wpf.Controls.DiffViewer`
- `DiffPlex.Wpf.Controls.SideBySideDiffViewer`
- `DiffPlex.Wpf.Controls.InlineDiffViewer`

### View mode context menu

You can right click the header to popup the context menu to select following actions.

- Switch mode between split (side-by-side) view and unified (inline) view.
- Toggle if need collapse unchanged sections.

![Context menu of header](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1724940/110648676-e0979a80-81f3-11eb-8dff-ea22f1928914.png)

Applied to following controls.

- `DiffPlex.Wpf.Controls.DiffViewer`

### WinForms demo

This PR also updates the WinForms demo by WPF element host implementation as I mentioned in #51 issue. It can be used in control or window of WinForms project and looks exactly as same as the one in WPF.

title: Use BenchmarkDotNet instead of the custom PerfTester
body:
In this PR I used [BenchmarkDotNet](https://benchmarkdotnet.org/) instead of custom PerfTest. Thanks to it we have:
- MemoryDiagnoser
- More reliable data - more info **[Pro .NET Benchmarking](https://www.apress.com/gp/book/9781484249406)**

**Results**
BenchmarkDotNet=v0.12.1, OS=Windows 10.0.18362.1082 (1903/May2019Update/19H1)
Intel Core i7-8565U CPU 1.80GHz (Whiskey Lake), 1 CPU, 8 logical and 4 physical cores
.NET Core SDK=5.0.100-rc.1.20452.10
  [Host]     : .NET Core 3.1.2 (CoreCLR 4.700.20.6602, CoreFX 4.700.20.6702), X64 RyuJIT
  DefaultJob : .NET Core 3.1.2 (CoreCLR 4.700.20.6602, CoreFX 4.700.20.6702), X64 RyuJIT


|         Method |     Mean |    Error |   StdDev |     Gen 0 |    Gen 1 |    Gen 2 | Allocated |
|--------------- |---------:|---------:|---------:|----------:|---------:|---------:|----------:|
| BuildDiffModel | 32.23 ms | 0.569 ms | 0.505 ms | 1031.2500 | 437.5000 | 156.2500 |   6.24 MB |

**Limitations**
I didn't want to change the behavior of the benchmark so it still generates different examples during runtime. It is not a good pattern.

**How to run**
```
cd Perf.DiffPlex
dotnet run -c Release -- --filter *
```

title: Exclude net35 reference assemblies from nuget package
body:
The `jnm2.ReferenceAssemblies.net35` is required only for the `net35` build, not for the other 2.

Both `jnm2.ReferenceAssemblies.net35` and `Microsoft.NETFramework.ReferenceAssemblies` is required for building the package and it's not necessary to publish a dependency on those libraries. Adding `PrivateAssets="All"` removes the dependency in the `.nuspec` file.

title: Add word-level diffs for WPF controls.
body:
Controls `DiffViewer`, `InternalLinesViewer` and `SideBySideDiffViewer` support sub-piece diffs by default now.

> Fix #53 issue.

It is dependent on that the diffs result `DiffPaneModel` computed from diff builder (such as `SideBySideDiffBuilder`) contains sub-pieces information.

Following is an example.

```xaml
<diffplex:DiffViewer x:Name="DiffView" />
```
```csharp
DiffView.OldText = oldText;
DiffView.NewText = newText;
```

![Diff sample](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1724940/77821651-d08fc380-7126-11ea-872c-3e3be8198239.png)

And following is another example.

```xaml
<diffplex:SideBySideDiffViewer x:Name="DiffView" />
```
```csharp
DiffView.SetDiffModel(OldText, NewText);
```

Note: It will be disabled when the text is too large (more than 3K lines) because of performance.

This PR also contains the changes of performance improvement to async render result for side-by-side mode.

title: Add helper functions
body:
Add some helper functions and singletons to make the usage of APIs more friendly. It is very useful for most of scenario.

## Sample

Following is a sample of _previous (current)_ vs _new (in PR)_.

```csharp
// Old (current).
var differ = new Differ();
var sideBySideBuilder = new SideBySideBuilder(differ);
var result = sideBySideBuilder.BuildDiffModel(oldText, newText);
```

```csharp
// New (in PR)
var result = SideBySideBuilder.Diff(oldText, newText);
```

And of course, this pull request keeps the old style to allow advanced customization and usages.

## Breaking changes

The `IDiffer` argument of constructors of `SideBySideDiffBuilder` and `InlineDiffBuilder` can be null now. A default `Differ` instance will be used when it is null.

## Helper functions

- `SideBySideDiffBuilder.Diff`
- `InlineDiffBuilder.Diff`

## Singletons

- `Differ.Instance`
- `WordChunker.Instance`
- `LineEndingsPreservingChunker.Instance`
- `LineChunker.Instance`
- `CharacterChunker.Instance`

## WPF controls

A benefit of the helper functions and singletons is that I add a new WPF control `DiffViewer` which we can set the old text and new text directly instead of an instance of `SideBySideDiffModel` or `DiffPaneModel`.

```xaml
<diffplex:DiffViewer />
```

The helper functions and the singletons will also decrease the memory cost for the scenario user create more instances of `Differ` class, diff builders and chunks.

title: Add WPF controls
body:
Contains following WPF controls in project `DiffPlex.Wpf`.

- `DiffPlex.Wpf.Controls.SideBySideDiffViewer` Side-by-side diffs viewer control.
- `DiffPlex.Wpf.Controls.InlineDiffViewer` Inline diffs viewer control.

You can customize the foregrounds and backgrounds for each change type of line.

### Sample

Following is an example for side by side diff viewer control.

```xaml
<diffplex:SideBySideDiffViewer x:Name="SideBySideDiff" />
```

```csharp
var builder = new SideBySideDiffBuilder(new Differ());
SideBySideDiff.DiffModel = builder.BuildDiffModel(OldText, NewText);
```

The project `DiffPlex.Wpf.Demo` is a simple demo you can see for details.

![DiffPlexWpfDemo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1724940/75887749-3741fa00-5e65-11ea-9086-9a11fbe6008b.png)

title: #47: Implement chunker that preserves line endings
body:
Hi
This PR should fix #47. I've made also a small refactoring by introducing `IChunker` interface which simplifies the `DIffer`. In my opinion, the `IDiffer` interface should be cut to:

```csharp
DiffResult CreateCustomDiffs(string oldText, string newText, bool ignoreWhiteSpace, bool ignoreCase, IChunker chunker);
```

and the rest of the overloads should be implemented as the extension methods. IMHO the name should be also simplified, let's say `CreateDiff`. Of course, these are breaking changes so I want to discuss it at first.

__EDIT__: I realized that this not enough to fix the problem because `InlineDiffBuilder` has hardcoded an invocation of specific overload from `IDiffer`. I needed to go further and I made another refactor by making an `IChunker` a constructor dependency for `DIffer` class. Now the `API` is much simpler and the extensibility and testability has been improved.

my previous pull-request was actually wrong for processing lines with the separator in the end. Like `one line `, it does not return tokens correctly

This should fix it, I added more tests covering all possible combinations

title: fixing "Differ" so that it doesn't generate so crazy amount of tokens…
body:
The problem can be demonstrated by diffing two outputs of following powershell script: 
```
(Get-Host).UI.RawUI.BufferSize = New-Object Management.Automation.Host.Size (4096, 4096)
Get-Process
```

This produce text output with many empty spaces and diffplex returns 8000 tokens for each line of code (for each space it returns 2 tokens)

The fix is just optimizing `SmartSplit` method to be smarter and aggregate spacing characters

All test passed here.

title: Side by side display issue
body:
I have been looking at the results that the side by side diff model returns. I have noticed that the position of modifications / imaginary lines on both sides appears incorrect if you have deleted text followed immediately by modified text.

Example: 
Line 2 from the left hand side has been deleted on the right, line 3 has been modified.
`This is line 1 | This is line 1`
`This is line 2 | This is line 3 With Modification`
`This is line 3 | This is line 4`
`This is line 4 | `

The model result for new text shows that line 1 was unchanged, line 2 was modified (not deleted), line 3 is marked as imaginary and line 4 is unchanged. It appears that in this scenario it should show line 2 as the imaginary (deleted line) and line 3 as the modified line. This is how the result is provided on other tests, when a delete is not directly followed by a modification.

Any thoughts on the above would be appreciated.

title: Is there any way to get a subjectively better character chunker?
body:
For example, I would like comparing "foo bar baz" and "foo bar fizz bazinga" to show a diff with inserting "fizz" and "inga", rather than inserting "fi" and "zinga".  In this example, my hope is that it could still be a character matcher, but prioritize later larger- or whole-token chunk matches over earlier small-chunk matches. 

Another such example is comparing "life, liberty, and property" to "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness, though not property".  It would be nice if this would report "the pursuit of happiness, though not" as an insert, rather than smaller chunks "proper" "y, and t" "e pursuit of h", etc.

title: InlineDiffBuilder needs an overload that takes ignoreCase parameter (and probably ignoreWhitespaces, too)
body:
InlineDiffBuilder.BuildDiffModel calls into IDiffer.CreateLineDiffs(oldText, newText, true), therefore hardcoding ignoreCase parameter to a default value, which is false, and also hardcoding ignoreWhitespace to true (per call done above). 
An overload to BuildDiffModel is needed to pass in ignoreCase (and probably ignoreWhitespace) parameters.

title: Add NuGet version badge to README
Target net35 as well as netstandard1.0
body:
I tested out 1.4.1 and because I'm using old-style `.csproj`/`packages.config` files and targeting `net45`, it included a whole bunch of `System.*` packages in my project.

This probably doesn't happen for users of the newer VS2017 `.csproj` file format, but it's straightforward to also include `net35` binaries in the same NuGet package. `msbuild` should do that automatically with this change.

Here is an example of the diff brought about after updating to 1.4.1.

```diff
 <packages>
-  <package id="DiffPlex" version="1.2.1" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="DiffPlex" version="1.4.1" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms" version="1.1.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="NETStandard.Library" version="1.6.1" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Collections" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Collections.Concurrent" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Diagnostics.Debug" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Diagnostics.Tools" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Diagnostics.Tracing" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Globalization" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.IO" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.IO.Compression" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Linq" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Linq.Expressions" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Net.Http" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Net.Primitives" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.ObjectModel" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Reflection" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Reflection.Extensions" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Reflection.Primitives" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Resources.ResourceManager" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Runtime.Extensions" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Runtime.InteropServices" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Runtime.InteropServices.RuntimeInformation" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Runtime.Numerics" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Text.Encoding" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Text.Encoding.Extensions" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Text.RegularExpressions" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Threading" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Threading.Tasks" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Xml.ReaderWriter" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="System.Xml.XDocument" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net45" />
 </packages>
```

I believe that if you can release this as 1.4.2 then it would instead be:

```diff
 <packages>
-  <package id="DiffPlex" version="1.4.1" targetFramework="net45" />
+  <package id="DiffPlex" version="1.4.2" targetFramework="net45" />
 </packages>
```

title: ArgumentOutOfRangeException
Semantics of word by word diff
body:
I'm trying to understand the semantics of word to word diff in diffplex w.r.t. wdiff.

Output from wdiff:

> ➜  git:(diffplex) ✗ echo "a b" > /tmp/a.txt  
> ➜  git:(diffplex) ✗ echo "a     b c" > /tmp/b.txt
> ➜  git:(diffplex) ✗ wdiff /tmp/a.txt /tmp/b.txt
> a     b {+c+}
> 

`{+c+}` means only "c" has been inserted.

If I try the same in diffplex word to word diff:
```
                var prev = "a b";
		var current = "a     b c";
		var differ = new Differ();
		var result = differ.CreateWordDiffs(prev, current, false, new char[] { ' ', '\n'});

		foreach (var block in result.DiffBlocks) 
		{
			Console.WriteLine();
			Console.WriteLine("Insert Start: {0}\nInsert Count: {1}\nDelete Start: {2}\nDelete Count: {3}",
			                  block.InsertStartB, block.InsertCountB, block.DeleteStartA, block.DeleteCountA);
		}
```

> Insert Start: 2
> Insert Count: 8
> Delete Start: 2
> Delete Count: 0
> 
> Insert Start: 11
> Insert Count: 2
> Delete Start: 3
> Delete Count: 0
> 

Converting ^^^ output into wdiff format will be like this: `a {+     +} b {+c+}`. I'm not sure of the semantics of word to word diff in diffplex. But I think output of wdiff is intuitive and desired most of the cases, and diffplex's output is resembles char to char diff. The output of diffplex is same even if I set `ignoreWhitespace=true` in `var result = differ.CreateWordDiffs(prev, current, true, new char[] { ' ', '\n'});`. Is it by design?

title: Generic diff utility for sequences of custom objects
body:
Python has a nice library called difflib [1], which has class `SequenceMatcher` that can diff not only string but also two difference sequences. Is there any plan to add something similar to `SequenceMatcher` to diffplex? The core algorithms in diffplex should work, just all the core classes have to be made generic and string specific code has to be refactored. This would be really good feature to add.

[1] : https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/difflib.html
[2]: https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/difflib.html#sequencematcher-objects

title: Get output similar to wdiff (*nix utility)
body:
I'm trying to get word by word diff similar to wdiff utility in *nix. Is there any way to achieve output similar to wdiff? 

For reference, this is the output format of wdiff:
```
➜  echo "ab xy" > /tmp/a.txt
➜  echo "bc xy" > /tmp/b.txt
➜  wdiff /tmp/a.txt /tmp/b.txt          
[-ab-]{+bc+} xy
```

title: Wrong side by side comparison
body:
It seems there are few issues with word-breaks processing (tested with side-by-side web UI):
1. Compare “**Hello,·World!**“ with “**Hello!**” – whole “old text” (“**Hello,·World!**”) is marked as _Deleted_. But actually “**Hello**” should be marked as “_Unchanged_”,  “**,·World**” as deleted and “**!**” as Unchanged.
2. Compare “**Hello,·World!**“ with “**Hi, Wordl!**” – “**Hello,**” is marked as Modified (comma included), but whould be better if only “**Hello**” is marked “_Modified_” and “**, World**” unchanged.

title: DNX support
body:
Added Core CLR support targeting net45 and dotnet TFMs i.e. .NET 4.5 onwards and Core CLR.

Converted 
- WebDiffer to ASP.NET Core project (kept the project in WebDiffer.old)
- Test project to use dnx runner for xunit tests

Addresses https://github.com/mmanela/diffplex/issues/12

An alternative way to support CoreCLR would be to convert the [existing PCL library to target .NET Core](https://oren.codes/2015/07/29/targeting-net-core/) using Oren Novotny's [ReferenceGenerator](https://github.com/onovotny/ReferenceGenerator), although this PR is probably more progressive in the direction the tooling is headed :smile: 

May need to [make .csproj and project.json play nicely together](http://blog.marcgravell.com/2015/11/the-road-to-dnx-part-1.html) (search for _This is actually slightly problematic_).

We have been using a MyGet hosted version of this for [NEST/Elasticsearch.Net](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-net) since January without issues.

title: API should take accept string[] for Lines
body:
AArnott[CodePlex]
Instead of forcing the entire buffers to be compared into a single String instance, an array of lines (string[]) should be accepted. Since it will be split into lines anyway this means you can reuse all those instances instead of creating them yourself. It also means that the maximum file you could operate on can increase because no object has to be too large.

title: New linked work item inherits iteration from parent only when autocreate is not ticked on
body:
Hi, I've just started using this plugin and it does exactly what I want, so thanks. 

I'm using it to try and make a template to add a set of tasks to a product backlog item. My one small quibble is that if I tick the checkbox to set the action to autocreate the tasks, then they don't inherit the product backlog item's current iteration. If I leave this ticked off, I have to save/close in the task dialog for each task that it creates, but it does seem to get the iteration. 

I'd like to be able to have it autocreate and inherit the iteration from the parent. Thanks.

title: @CurrentIteration is not working within Templates
body:
When I use the @CurrentIteration statement to create a new "task" under a "work Item" states an error. The error is:
"Error: TF401347: Invalid tree name given for work item -1, field 'System.IterationPath'.. Please check the template used in this action."

This is when autocration is set. When I remove autocreate I can create new work Items from the template (without current iteration path) and it fills the current iteration path for me. When I set the autocreate again the new tasks are placed on top level iteration creating orphan tasks.

Please help.

Thanks in advance.

title: OneClick: New Linked Item with Templates using macros error on execution
body:
Creating a new linked item using a template that assigns Iteration Path = `@CurrentIteration` errors during execution. The template will apply correctly when applied in the work item dialog via standard VSTS application, but errors when applied via OneClick. Specifying an explicit iteration path allows the OneClick action to work as expected.

In the example, the OneClick action applies to a PBI, and creates a child Task using a Work Item Template that assigns Iteration Path = `@CurrentIteration`. Auto create work item is enabled. The OneClick action does not have an associated Trigger.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7827396/41068818-210831e8-69a0-11e8-9f7e-984ea2c93ceb.png)
